dialogues.speaker: INT. MADAME DE MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: The gilt frame around the mirror on the MARQUISE DE MERTEUIL's dressing-table encloses the reflection of her beautiful face. For a moment she examines herself; critically, but not without satisfaction. Then she begins to apply her make-up. ANOTHER ANGLE shows the whole large room, the early : afternoon light filtering through gauze curtains. MERTEUI CHAMBERMAID stands behind her, polishing her shoulders wi crushed mother-of-pearl. Three or four other female SERVA wait, disposed around the room. It's midsummer in Paris i 1788.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VICOMTE DE VALMONT'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT is an indistinct shape in his vast bed. His valet de-chambre, AZOLAN leads a troupe of male SERVANTS into t room. One raises the blind and opens enough of a curtain to admit some afternoon light, another waits with a cup o chocolate steaming on a tray, a third carries a damp flan in a bowl. As VALMONT stirs, his face still unseen, AZOLA takes the flannel, leans over and begins a perfunctory dr wash.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A steel hook moves to and fro, deftly tightening MME DE MERTEUIL's corset.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT's face is swathed in hot towels, his head tilted A young MANICURIST, on his knees, attends to VALMONT's na Several other SERVANTS wait gravely to play their part in elaborate ritual of dressing VALMONT. The BARBER produces a pair of tweezers and delicately plucks a hair from one VALMONT's nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A second dressing-table is covered with extravagant numbe perfume boxes. MERTEUIL, now in corset, chemise and under sits, surrounded by her MAIDS. Eventually she makes a cho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 ll Continued and indicates a box. A MAID opens the box and begins to apply the perfume (in the form of a cream) to MERTEUIL's lightly massaging it in. Meanwhile, MERTEUIL smells the contents of another box and hands it to a second MAID, wh begins applying it to MERTEUIL's armpit.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: AZOLAN opens a walk-in closet, which contains innumerable of boots and shoes. He and another SERVANT choose a coupl pairs of shoes each and bring them out. VALMONT's hand co INTO SHOT, indicating a black pair with red heels. AZOLAN hands them to a BOOTBOY, who hurries away, breathing on t as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL'S MAID makes a final adjustment to the bamboo si panniers hanging from MERTEUIL's waist, then motions two MAIDS to cover them with an embroidered petticoat.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANTE-ROOM TO VALMONT'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT's PERRUQUIER waits attentively as VALMONT, seen from behind, stands in front of the three tiers of featur wooden heads which carry his collection of wigs. Eventual he points to one.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL's stomacher is now in position and she stands, a outstretched, as two MAIDS move forward with her dress, g her arms into it as if it were an overcoat. This done, MERTEUIL's SEAMSTRESS approaches and begins the delicate process of sewing her into her dress.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANTE-ROOM TO VALMONT'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: A bizarre metal cone with gauze-covered eyeholes conceals VALMONT's face as the PERRUQUIER blows powder at his wig. the powder drifts away, VALMONT slowly lowers the cone an we see for the first time his intelligent and malicious features. ANOTHER ANGLE shows the complete magnificent ensemble; or not quite complete, for AZOLAN now reaches his arms round VALMONT's waist to strap on his sword.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S TOWN-HOUSE DUSK
dialogues.text: A panoramic view of the great room. In one corner MERTEUI is playing piquet with her cousin MME DE VOLANGES; in the centre of the room, the huge chandelier has been lowered within a foot of the floor and two FOOTMEN with tapers ar lighting its candles; and at the window itself is a demur 15-year-old blonde: CECILE VOLANGES. The CAMERA closes in on her, as ON SOUND we hear the arri of a carriage, clattering into the paved courtyard below.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD DUSK
dialogues.text: CECILE'S P.O.V.: below, the handsome black carriage comes to a halt. The FOOTMAN clinging to the back jumps down, runs back, opens the door, lowers the step and stan back. Presently the VICOMTE DE VALMONT emerges, resplende

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON DUSK
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON CECILE, as she looks down at VALMONT, curious. The chandelier is fully lit now and one of the FOOTMEN begins to raise it. MME DE MERTEUIL's perfect, mask-like face gradually becom fully-lit as the chandelier rises. She's looking not at her cards but across the long expanse of the room at CECI profile. Eventually she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Well, my dear... CECILE doesn't at first realise it's she who's being addressed: then she starts and half-turns.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULIL
dialogues.text: So how are you adapting to the outside world?

dialogues.speaker: ' CECILE
dialogues.text: Very well. I think.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: I've advised her to watch and learn and be quiet except when spoken to. MERTEUIL looks CECILE up and down, frankly appraising her

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: We must see what we can devise for your amusement. The mirrored double-doors open and MERTEUIL's MAJORDOMIO, carrying a silver tray, advances unhurriedly across the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued At the table, the large playing cards slap down on one another. MERTEUIL glances up at her MAJORDOMO and reaches for the card on his tray. She replaces the card, looks up at him and nods. The MAJORDOMO departs and MERTEUIL speak quietly to VOLANGES.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Valmont is here. VOLANGES reacts with a trace of alarm.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: You receive him, do you?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Yes. So do you. VOLANGES turns to her daughter, whose interest has been caught by this exchange.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Vicomte de Valmont, my child, whom you very probably don't remember, except that he is conspicuously charming, never opens his mouth without first calculating what damage he can do.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: They why do you receive him, Maman?

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Everyone receives him. She breaks off as the MAJORDOMO reappears, escorting VALMONT, who crosses to bow formally to MERTEUIL in a ges which also takes in the’ others.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Madame.

dialogues.speaker: ' MERTEULL
dialogues.text: Vicomte.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: What a pleasant surprise.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Madame de Volanges. How delight- ful to see you.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES ,
dialogues.text: You remember my daughter, Cecile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, indeed, but who could have foretold she would flower so gracefully? CECILE simpers, blushing and looking away. VALMONT turns back to MERTEUIL.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I wanted to call on you before leaving the city.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm not sure we can allow that. Why should you want to leave?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Paris in August, you know: and it's time I paid a visit on my old aunt, I've neglected her . disgracefully.

dialogues.speaker: / VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Madame de Rosemonde has been good enough to invite us to stay at the chateau. Will you please give her our warmest regards?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shall make a point of it, Madame. VOLANGES puts down her cards and rises decisively, addressing CECILE.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: I think it's time we took you home. CECILE responds, still nervously aware of VALMONT's unwavering stare. ’

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I'm used to being in bed by nine at the convent.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: So I should hope. She breaks away, mysteriously alarmed, and hurries across to VOLANGES. WMERTEUIL has summoned a FOOTMAN. VALMONT bows and we watch from his P.O.V. as the FOOTMAN shows ou VOLANGES and CECILE. When they've gone, MERTEUIL crosses back towards VALMONT, speaking in an entirely different t of voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Your aunt?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: That's right,

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I thought she'd already made arrangements to leave you all her money. He smiles without answering. She arrives beside him. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Do you know why I summoned you here this evening?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'd hoped it might be for the pleasure of my company.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I need you; to carry out a heroic enterprise. You remember when Bastide left me? VALMONT feigns a sympathetic expression.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: And went off with that fat mistress of yours whose name escapes me.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: No one has ever done that to me before. Or to you I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I was quite relieved to be rid of her, frankly.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: No, you weren't. She now has his undivided attention.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: For some years now, Bastide has been searching for a wife. He was always unshakeably prejudiced in favour of convent education. and now he's found the ideal candidate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CONVENT Day CECILE, superintended by a couple of NUNS, waits inside a enclosure, her face framed between the bars of a wooden Partition. a VALMONT (V.0.) Cecile Volanges.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONVENT DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE VOLANGES's magnificent carriage, silhouetted again the walls of the convent.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And her sixty thousand a year, that must have played some part in his calculations. ANOTHER ANGLE. A FOOTMAN helps MME DE VOLANGES down from the carriage.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: None whatsoever. His priority, you see, is a guaranteed virtue. INT. CONVENT Day MME DE VOLANGES hasn't seen CECILE in years. She advances uncertainly towards her and they exchange a tentative emb through the partition.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I wonder if'I'm beginning to guess what it is you're intending to propose. A NUN opens the half-door to release CECILE. ‘ MERTEUIL (V.0.) Bastide is with his regiment in Corsica for the rest of the year.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: That should give you plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You mean to...?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: She's a rosebud.  r 3 18 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You think so?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: i And he'd get back from honeymoon to find himself the laughing- stock of Paris.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Yes. Love and revenge: two of your favourites. | Silence. VALMONT considers for a moment. Finally, he shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P) Really, I can't.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It's too easy. It is. What is she, fifteen, she's seen nothing, she knows nothing, she's bound to be curious, she'd be on her back before you'd unwrapped the first : bunch of flowers. Any one of a dozen men could manage it. I. have my reputation to think of. MERTEUIL frowns, displeased. VALMONT hesitates, looking aft her.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I can see I'm going to have to tell you everything.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Of course you are.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: cr ) Yes. Well. My aunt is not on her own just at the moment. She has a young friend staying with her: Madame dé Tourvel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You can't mean it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FORMAL GARDENS OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL's strong, beautiful, untroubled face, as she moves through the gardens. She's accompanied. by VALM 80-year-old aunt, MME DE ROSEMONDE, who chooses flowers, which MME DE TOURVEL then cuts and lays in a basket.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: To seduce a woman famous for atrict morals, religious fervour and the happiness of her marriage: what could possibly be more prestigious?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I think there's something degrading about having a husband for a rival. It's humiliating if you fail and commonplace if you succeed. Where is M. de Tourvel anyway?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Presiding over some endless case in Burgundy.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON DUSK
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL frowns at VALMONT, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: I don't think you can hope for any actual pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. And I have no intention of breaking down her prejudices. ‘ TY want her to boliovo im Coed and virtue and the sanctity of marriage and still not be able to stop herself. I want passion, in other words. I want the excitement of watching her betray everything that's most important to her. Surely you under- stand that. I thought betrayal was your favourite word.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: No, no, cruelty: I always think that has a nobler ring to it. VALMONT smiles; but MERTEUIL turns on him, her expression serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y a ° 10 20 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm surprised at you. You might just as well be in love.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I haven't felt so strongly about t anything since you and I were together. That's why I intend to ’ have her, to rescue myself from this ridiculous position.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Love is something you use, not something you fall into, like ! quicksand, don't you remember? y It's like medicine, you use it ' as a lubricant to nature. He returns, a little uneasily, her challenging gaze.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR OF MIRRORS DUSK
dialogues.text: -~ . The first-floor landing in MERTEUIL's house is an im 3) gallery of mirrors. She and VALMONT pass down the corr their images shifting and multiplying in the candle-light

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: How's Belleroche?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm very pleased with him.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And is he your only lover? MERTEUIL pretends to give this a moment's consideration.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I think you should take another, I think it most unhealthy, this exclusivity.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You're not jealous, are you? ” VALMONT t ‘5 Of course I am. Belleroche is a completely undeserving.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I thought he was one of your closest friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: il Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Exactly, so I know what I'm talking about. No, I think you should organise an infidelity. With me, for example.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You refuse me a simple favour and then you expect to be indulged?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It's only because it is so simple. It wouldn't feel like a conquest. I have to follow my destiny. I have to be true to my profession.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN STAIRCASE DUSK
dialogues.text: VALMONT pauses at the top of the broad and imposing stair which leads down to the entrance of the house. MERTEUIL watches him for a moment, amused: then she comes to an unexpected decision.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: All right, then: come back when you've succeeded with Madame de Tourvel.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: And I will offer you...a reward.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: My love.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: But I shall require proof.

dialogues.speaker: ' VALMONT
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Written proof.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Not negotiable. VALMONT recovers quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 24 25 26 12 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I don't suppose there's any possibility of an advance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Vicomte. He kisses her hand and hurries down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR OF MIRRORS DUSK
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL stops in front of one of the mirrors. It turns out to be a door, which she opens.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPIRAL STAIRCASE DUSK
dialogues.text: A candle at the top sheds a dim light; MERTEUIL begins to ascend her secret staircase.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BEDROOM DUSK
dialogues.text: BELLEROCHE, a beautiful blockhead of about 30, springs to his feet as MERTEUIL emerges from what is ostensibly a cupboard door. He hurries over to embrace her.

dialogues.speaker: BELLEROCHE
dialogues.text: Where have you been? Time has no logic when I'm not with you: an hour is like a century.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I've told you before: we shall get on a good deal better if you make a concerted effort not to sound like the latest novel. He looks hurt; she kisses him affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE CHAPEL IN MME DE ROSEMONDE'S GROUNDS DAY
dialogues.text: The sound of the little silver bell which summons the congregation to take Communion: CLOSE ON MME DE TOURVEL as her hands part to reveal her face. MME DE ROSEMONDE kneels next to her and is now being helped to her feet by VALMONT. VALMONT escorts ROSEMONDE up the stairs to the altar-rail TOURVEL remaining on the other side of her. The rest of the congregation consists of ROSEMONDE's domestic staff, in a segregated portion of the chapel; and they file up towards the altar, respectfully waiting their turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 Continued TOURVEL kneels at the altar-rail as VALMONT helps ROSEMON to kneel beside her. Then TOURVEL looks up, slightly surprised, as VALMONT moves off to one side, instead of taking his place at the rail. By now, the elderly CURE, intoning the Latin mass, is approaching TOURVEL with the large Communion wafer. VALMONT watches intently. VALMONT'S P.O.V.: the wafer is placed on TOURVEL's lower lip and slowly vanishes into her mouth. She looks up at h TOURVEL'S P.O.V.: VALMONT, his expression respectful, his demeanour hunble.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CHAPEL DAY
dialogues.text: Beautiful summer's day. The chapel is in the grounds of MME DE ROSEMONDE's chateau, the turrets of which are visi in the distance. Her open carriage stands waiting, as the congregation emerges into the sunlight. The COACHMAN jump down, but MME DE ROSEMONDE dismisses him with a gesture.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: It's such a beautiful day, I believe we'll walk. AZOLAN attends to VALMONT, taking his prayer-book and handing him his cane; while MME DE TOURVEL's chambermaid, JULIE, is helping her mistress with her bonnet.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODLAND PATH DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE ROSEMONDE and the CURE lead the way, deep in conversation, followed at a distance by VALMONT and MME D TOURVEL. AZOLAN and JULIE bring up the rear.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You didn't take the sacrament today.

dialogues.speaker: ' VALMONT
dialogues.text: I felt L couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: May I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I have this appalling reputation as you may know...

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I have been warned about you. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 29 30 14 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You have? By whom?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: A friend.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, well, I suppose a warning might be justified. I've spent my life surrounded by immoral people; I've allowed myself to be influenced by them and sometimes even taken pride in outshining them.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: And now?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Now what I feel most often is unworthiness.

dialogues.speaker: . TOURVEL
dialogues.text: But it's precisely at such moments you start to become worthy. VALMONT appears to give this assertion his serious consideration. He glances back over his shoulder and notices that AZOLAN is murmuring with some intimacy into JULIE's ear. Then he turns back to MME D= TOURVEL.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I certainly believe that one should constantly strive to improve oneself. LONG SHOT of the two of ‘them, strolling along the dapple path, as, on SOUND, the passionate climax of a Gluck aria begins to swell.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX AT THE OPERA EVENING
dialogues.text: The aria continues, the opera is in progress. MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE, in the box, stare down at the Stage. MME DE MERTEUIL, however, opera-glasses pressed to her fa is scanning the audience.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OPERA HOUSE EVENING
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL'S P.O.V., as her gaze comes to rest on the face of a handsome young man of not more than twenty, listenin intently, tears streaming down his face: the CHEVALIER DANCENY.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX EVENING
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL lowers her opera-glasses, pensive.

dialogues.speaker: INT. OPERA HOUSE EVENING
dialogues.text: The interval, and the fashionable audience goes about its principal business of the evening: gossip and celebrity- spotting. DANCENY moves through the auditorium, still in something of a trance; and is startled by the arrival of a uniformed FOOTMAN, who hands him a note on a silver tra

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX EVENING
dialogues.text: A knock at the door and DANCENY, charmingly shy and uncer bows deeply to MERTEUIL.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Chevalier, I don't. believe you know my cousin, Madame de Volanges. This is Chevalier Danceny. And Madame's daughter, Cecile. All this has taken place very quickly and now DANCENY bec aware of CECILE for the first time: he looks at her, tong tied, obviously smitten, eventually managing to utter a strangled greeting. MERTEUIL observes him shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Tell us what we should think of the opera.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Oh, it's sublime. Don't you find?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Why do these composers keep choosing identical subjects?

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: But this is infinitely the better ‘ version. Piccini is a mere opportunist.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Monsieur Danceny is one of those rare eccentrics who come here to listen to the music.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I do look forward to our next meeting. He bows to CECILE, blushing deeply and leaves the box. CECILE's eyes are shining. MERTEUIL is watching her closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Charming young man. Penniless, regrettably. He's one of the finest music-teachers in the city. CLOSE on CECILE: the idea occurs to her at the very moment MERTEUIL expresses it.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Perhaps you should employ him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GROUNDS OF THE CHATEAU DAWN
dialogues.text: VALMONT and AZOLAN, who carries a long musket over his shoulder, crunch across the gravel. As they pass, a PAN reveals MME DE TOURVEL's footman, GEORGES, following them huddled in an angle of the building.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MME DE TOURVEL'S BEDROOM DAWN
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL stands, a corner of the curtain raised, looking down at VALMONT and AZOLAN.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS DAWN
dialogues.text: VALMONT speaks abruptly to AZOLAN, surprising him in mid- yawn.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: How are you getting on’ with Madame de Tourvel's maid?

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Julie? Tell you the truth, it's been a bit boring. Lf I wasn't so anxious to keep your Lordship abreast, I think I'd have only bothered the once. Still, you know, what else is there ‘ to do in the country?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, it wasn't so much the details of your intimacy I was after, it was whether she's agreed to bring me Madame de Tourvel's letters.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: She won't steal the letters, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: She won't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 37 38 39 17 Continued

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: You know better than me, sir, it's easy enough making them do what they want to do; it's trying to get them to do what you want them to do, that's what gives you a headache.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And them, as often as not. I need to know who's writing to her about me.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: I shouldn't worry if I was you, sir. She told Julie she didn't believe you went hunting in the mornings. She said she was going to have you followed. So I'd say it was only a matter of time. They carry on through the woods. Behind them, GEORGES blunders incompetently from tree to tree.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOUNDARY OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S LAND DAY
dialogues.text: AZOLAN unlocks a gate in the wall enclosing ROSEMONDE's property to let VALMONT through. The latter hesitates, looking back.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Terrible noise he's making.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: He'll get the news back to her twice as quickly.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I don't think we should make ’ . it too easy for him. He takes the musket from AZOLAN and suddenly fires it into the undergrowth.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UNDERGROWTH DAY
dialogues.text: GEORGES, panic-stricken, hurls himself to the ground as the echoes of the shot die away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOUNDARY OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S LAND DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT hands the musket back to AZOLAN and closes the ga behind them. The wall stretches away as far as the eye ca see. The two men grin at each other and hurry on.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. VILLAGE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: The village consists of half-a-dozen wattle-and-daub huts, disposed around a muddy clearing; where pigs graze and bare-foot children wander. The poverty is as stark an absolute as that of a village in India. A small crowd is gathered around one of the huts, out of which a couple of MEN, supervised by the BAILIFF are carrying out a plain deal table, which they dump down next to three wooden cha A gaunt WOMAN follows them, miserably wringing her hands. GEORGES hurries across the square, reaching the fringes o the crowd just as VALMONT steps forward to confront the BAILIFF.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What exactly do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: I am impounding these effects, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Has it not been explained to you? M. Armand is not well. BAILIFF . I don't make the laws, sir, I just do what I'm told. Everybody has to pay his taxes.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: How much does he owe?

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: BALLIFF
dialogues.text: Fifty-six livres. VALMONT takes a large, jingling purse out of his pocket and hands it to AZOLAN.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Pay him.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Yes, my lord. Gasps from the crowd; even a ripple of applause. VALMONT marches forward and vanishes into the hut.  41 42

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 INT. ARMAND'S HUT Day Standing on the straw spread over the mud floor, in the heat of the more or less unventilated, dingy hut, looking down at M. ARMAND, (a man of not more than 50, who looks ancient, gnarled and battered by work, with long, thick white hair), VALMONT has to make an effort not to be overcome by the fetid atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You don't know me...

dialogues.speaker: ARMAND
dialogues.text: Of course I do, M. le Vicomte.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ah. No, please, don't get up. ARMAND is struggling up-.out of his large pallet bed covered with sacking.

dialogues.speaker: ARMAND
dialogues.text: I have to, sir. They're taking the bed.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Not at all, M. Armand. No one is taking anything.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARMAND'S HUT DAY
dialogues.text: The crowd scatters as VALMONT emerges from the hut. He approaches the BAILIFF.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Kindly instruct your men to replace M. Armand's furniture. The gaunt WOMAN approaches VALMONT; she's accompanied by a toil-worn younger COUPLE and a pair of thin, sickly- looking CHILDREN. ‘ WOMAN You're an angel sent from heaven. Suddenly, all of them are on their knees to VALMONT. Genuinely touched, he. looks across at AZOLAN, then manag to free a hand to reach for his purse. AZOLAN passes it to him and he fetches out a handful of gold, pressing it into the WOMAN's reluctant hand.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Just to tide you over. IL insist. Again the crowd bursts into spontaneous applause. GEORGES watches thoughtfully. .

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOUNDARY OF MME DE ROSEMONDE'S LAND DAY
dialogues.text: AZOLAN unlocks a compartment in one of the brick gatepost and takes out a wooden mailbox with a slot in the top. Then he takes a pin from his wig and begins delicately to probe the loek of the mailbox as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-six livres to save an entire family from ruin, that seems a genuine bargain.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: These days, my lord, you can find half-a-dozen like that, any village in the country. VALMONT oe Really? I must say the family was very well chosen. Solidly respectable, gratifyingly tearful, no suspiciously pretty girls. Well done. :

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: I do my best for you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And all that humble gratitude. It was most affecting. AZOLAN “ Certainly brought a tear to my eye. The lock yields to his manipulations, the mailbox opens a after a brief inspection he hands two letters to VALMONT, who glances at the postmarks and hands one of them straig back to AZOLAN. .

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Dijon. That's from her husband. He holds the other letter which is ina distinctive, somewhat pretentious envelope, up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'm sure this must be from that officious friend of hers. He passes it back to AZOLAN, who returns it to the mailbo and closes it. They move off, back in the direction of th house.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Tell me, where do you and Julie meet? . AZOLAN non Oh, in my room, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And is she coming tonight?

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Then I think I may have to burst in on you. See if blackmail will succeed better than bribery. About two o'clock suit you? I don't want to embarrass you, will that give you enough time?

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Ample, sir. In the background GEORGES has come through the gate. He unlocks the mailbox and takes out the letters it contains.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN THE CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT looks up from his book, as MME DE ROSEMONDE bustl into the room, followed by MME DE TOURVEL. He rises to greet them.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Is this true about M. Armand?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I don't believe I know anyone of that name...

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You may as well own up, Monsieur. My footman happened to be passing when you were in the village this morning. ‘ VALMONT I don't think you ought to pay too much attention to servants gossip.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: It is true, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, I...it's simply...Yes. He looks up, ostensibly deeply embarrassed, to catch MME TOURVEL's admiring gaze. MME DE ROSEMONDE spreads her arm

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: You dear boy. come and let me give you a hug!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 Continued VALMONT crosses to her and they embrace. Then VALMONT turns and advances towards MME DE TOURVEL. Before she can escape, he's embraced her and, for a second, she's in his arms. Meanwhile MME DE ROSEMONDE's STEWARD has entered, with the mail laid out on a salver. As MME DE. TOURVEL escapes from VALMONT's arms, she finds the STEWAR at her elbow. Ashen, she shakily reaches out her hand for the two letters. INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE Day CECILE is playing the harp and singing a song, accompanie by DANCENY on the harpsichord. On the far side of the roo are MERTEUIL and VOLANGES, paying far more attention to their murmured conversation than to the music. After a ti DANCENY breaks off, hitting a note several times to indic where CECILE's voice has gone wrong. They resume a few ba back; this time CECILE gets it right and DANCENY nods in approval. They proceed until CECILE makes a mistake with harp. DANCENY stops and comes over to join her. He plays the complicated little phrase. CECILE tries it, but can't manage it. He takes her hands and adjusts them to the correct position. She almost plays the phrase correctly, looks up at him smiling.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Try it again. She does so and gets it right.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Very good. As he turns away, he slips a piece of paper between the h strings. CECILE frowns, then, as he arrives back at the harpsichord, she snatches it and unfolds it. On it is a message written in pencil: I LOVE YOU. Blushing furiously, she crumples the piece of paper and s it into her pocket. Then she darts an angry glance at DAN ’

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: This is very difficult, I'm afraid. Can we start again? He begins to play and CECILE, with a great effort, manage to come in almost on cue.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX AT. THE OPERA EVENING
dialogues.text: The opera is in full swing. MERTEUIL and CECILE murmur to one another in the darkened box, neither paying the slightest attention to the stage below.  46 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Would it be very wrong of me to answer M. Danceny's letters?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: In the circumstances, yes.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: In what circumstances? MERTEUIL pretends to reflect before answering.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: It's not my place to tell you this, my dear...if I hadn't become so fond of you...

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Go on, please!

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Your marriage has been arranged. CECILE gapes at her: but this has not come as a total surprise and her curiosity quickly overcomes her alarm.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Someone I know, slightly. M le Comte de Bastide.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: You don't like him.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: It's not that. He's a man of somewhat...erratic judgment. And rather serious.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Thirty-six.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Thirty-six? He's an old man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “) 46 47 24 Continued MERTEUIL smiles, as another thought galvanises CECILE.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Do you know when?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: In the new year, I believe. She stares, unseeing, at the stage, lost in thought. MERTEUIL leans in closer to her.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Perhaps there is a way to let you write to M. Danceny...

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Oh, Madame! She's caught hold of MERTEUIL's hand, her eyes shining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to show me both sides of the correspondence, I could reassure myself... CECILE throws herself into MERTEUIL's arms and embraces her. MERTEUIL's eyes glitter in the darkness. Then CECILE looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I can't show you the letters I've already sent him... She breaks off, realising she's given herself away, her expression apprehensive. But MERTEUIL's smile is indulgen As the impassioned love-duet on stage reaches a climax, phe stretches out a hand to caress CECILE's neck and coll one.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN THE CHATEAU NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT is reading and MME DE TOURVEL is looking over her letter from Paris, the one with the distinctive envelope. Eventually, she looks up at him and breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I can't understand how someone whose instincts are so generous, could lead such a dissolute life.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'm afraid you have an exaggerated idea both of my generosity and of my depravity. If I knew who'd given you such a dire account of me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 Continued MME DE TOURVEL folds up her letter, her expression sheepi

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The truth is, the key to the paradox lies in a certain weakness of character.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: How could so thoughtful an act of charity be described as weak?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT -
dialogues.text: Because it was performed purely in response to your influence.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I have tried to set you a good example these last two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And you've succeeded. What I did today was nothing more than an innocent tribute to your goodness. MME DE TOURVEL looks away. VALMONT sighs.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You see how weak I am? I promised myself I was never going to tell you. It's just, looking at you...

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You needn't worry, I have no illicit intentions. I wouldn't dream of insulting you. But I do love you. I adore you. The letter slips from MME DE TOURVEL's fingers. VALMONT is across the room in an instant, on his knees in front o her, handing her the letter and then taking her hand in h

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Please help me. As MME DE TOURVEL wrenches her hands free, a door opens t admit MME DE ROSEMONDE's STEWARD. In the ensuing confusio TOURVEL gets up, snatches a candlestick, and hurries out the room, leaving VALMONT momentarily floundering.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN STAIRCASE NIGHT
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL hurries up the vast, wide staircase. Below, VALMONT, in pursuit, emerges into the hallway,

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL's back recedes down the corridor. Presently, VALMONT comes into frame, catching her up. But TOURVEL disappears into her room and there's the sound of a heavy bolt. VALMONT arrives at her door and drops to his knees, pressing his eye to her keyhole.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: KEYHOLE SHOT: MME DE TOURVEL crosses to the window and stands looking out into the night, her expression trouble

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT stands up. There's a look of satisfaction on his face as he begins to tiptoe away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AZOLAN'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: AZOLAN is in bed with JULIE, they're asleep in each other arms. Suddenly the door bursts open. VALMONT stands in th doorway in his dressing gown, holding a candlestick. In i flickering light, AZOLAN and JULIE wake, JULIE genuinely terrified and AZOLAN (since this has been prearranged) convincingly dismayed.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I rang a number of times.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Didn't hear, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: ’ I require some hot water.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Right away, sir. He jumps out of bed, uncovering JULIE. She reaches for th sheets but VALMONT speaks sharply, stopping her in her tr

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Don't move. As AZOLAN puts on a dressing gown and hurries to the door VALMONT settles himself on the end of the bed, his eyes burning into JULIE.  27 2 ~ 52 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Azolan.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Wait for me in my room. AZOLAN hurries out. VALMONT continues to stare at JULIE, who is becoming increasingly uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I can't condone this sort of behaviour, you know, Julie.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: I know, sir, I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: But you may rely on my discretion...

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: rf) Oh, thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: +++ providing, of course, that you agree to my price. There's a silence, during which JULIE thinks she understa what he means. Her expression changes as she tries to wor out how best to react. But VALMONT shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, nothing like that. No, all I want is to see every letter Mme de Tourvel has received since her arrival here and every letter she writes from now on.

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: ’ But, sir...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Deliver them to Azolan by midnight _ tomorrow. He stands, continuing to look at her for a moment, until she snatches at the sheet and covers herself. He brings a handful of gold coins out of his dressing-gown pocket *) and bangs them down on the dresser.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: For your trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 EXT. GARDENS OF THE CHATEAU pay MME DE TOURVEL rounds the right-angle of a manicured hedg and stops dead in her tracks. Bearing down on her is VALMONT. She turns in confusion, but there's evidently no escape and in a moment he's with her, bowing deep.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have spoken to you like that yesterday, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I thought the least I could hope for was that you would respect me.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I don't want you to think this has anything to do with your beauty. I know now that beauty is the least of your qualities. L've become fascinated by your goodness. I couldn't understand what was happening to me and it was only when I began to feel actual physical pain every time you left the room, that it finally dawned on me: I was in love, for the first time in my life.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I really will have to leave you, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, please, tell me what to do, show me how to behave, I'll do anything you say. MME DE TOURVEL has turned away from him; now, after a moment's thought, she turns back.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: There's only one thing I would like you to do for me.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I want to put myself in the position of being beholden to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please, I insist.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Very well, then, I would like you to return to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 53 29 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I don't see why that should be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Let's just say you've spent your life making it necessary. By now VALMONT has recovered his equilibrium and thought very fast.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shall find something in my mail tomorrow morning which obliges me to return to Paris.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Thank you, I'd be very grateful. She begins to move away. VALMONT lets her go two or three steps before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: . VALMONT
dialogues.text: Perhaps I might ask a favour in return? MME DE TOURVEL frowns, hesitating.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I think it would only be just to let me know which of your friends has blackened my name.

dialogues.speaker: . TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You know very well that's impossible, Monsieur. If friends of mine have warned me against you, they've done so purely in my own interest. I could hardly reward them with betrayal!

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Very well, I withdraw the request. Will you at least allow me to write to you?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And hope that you will do me the kindness of answering my letters?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm not sure a correspondence with you is something a woman of honour could permit herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 30 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: So you're determined to refuse my suggestions, however respectable?

dialogues.speaker: . TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I would welcome the chance to prove to you that what motivates me in rhis is not hatred or resentment ut...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: But what? MME DE TOURVEL seems unable to find a satisfactory answer to this.

dialogues.speaker: INT. AZOLAN'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: There's a knock at the door: AZOLAN makes a wry face and lets in JULIE. He embraces her; but what has immediately caught his interest is the bundle of letters in her hand. As soon as he decently can, he extricates himself from th embrace and takes the letters from her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM DAWN
dialogues.text: VALMONT sits at a bureau, inspecting the letters, his expression indignant. AZOLAN stands to one side, looking complacent.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Listen to this: ‘Just as every good man has his weaknesses, every criminal has his virtues. So be doubly careful of the Vicomte de Valmont.’ He turns the letter over and reads out the signature, nod grimly.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Madame de Volanges.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN ENTRANCE TO THE CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT embraces MME DE ROSEMONDE as his. big black carri waits at the foot of a flight of outside steps. MME DE TOURVEL waits, a little to one side. VALMONT crosses to her, takes her hand and kisses it, taking her by surprise She tries to withdraw her hand but he holds on to it. She speaks in an undertone.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Monsieur, please...  56 57

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 Continued He releases her hand and adds, in a murmur.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'll write soon.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMILIE'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT is making energetic love to EMILIE, a strikingly attractive courtesan, in her luxurious canopied bed. After a while, he sighs with pleasure and pulls away from her. Outside, there are occasional rumbles of thunder and flashes of lightning. He looks down at her for a moment, leaning on one elbow.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Turn over. EMILIE hesitates, looking up at him for a moment. Then she breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: All right. She turns over and looks up at him expectantly. He twitch away the bedclothes and contemplates her briefly, before speaking, very businesslike.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Do you have pen, ink and writing paper?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: Yes, over there, in the bureau. Why? Puzzled, she watches him as he gets up, crosses the room, finds what he's looking for and brings it. back to the be He puts down the pen and inkwell carefully, then climbs on to EMILIE, spreads a sheet of paper across the small of her back, arranges himself comfortably and reaches for the pen.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Now, don't move. EMILIE is still puzzled, but she submits graciously enoug VALMONT begins to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: ‘My dear Madame de Tourvel... I have just come...to my desk...' EMILIE understands now. She turns her head to smile up at him.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Don't move, I said. '...in the middle of a stormy night, during which I have been tossed from exaltation to exhaustion and back again. The position in which I find myself as I write has made me more than ever aware of the power of love...'

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S BEDROOM AT THE CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL sits at her bureau, reading VALMONT's lett

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: '...I can-scarcely control myself sufficiently to put my thoughts in order; but despite these torments, I guarantee that at this moment I am far happier than you...' The letter: a teardrop falls on to the paper, smudging th ink.

dialogues.speaker: INT. EMILIE'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: EMILIE is reaching back to caress VALMONT as he writes.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: '...I hope one day you may feel the kind of disturbance afflicting me now: meanwhile please excuse me while I take steps to calm what I can only describe as a mounting excitement.' He moves aside paper, pen and inkwell and lies forward to murmur in EMILIE's ear.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: We'll finish it later, shall we?  60

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: It's September now and there's a hint of Autumn in the afternoon light. VALMONT is taking tea with the MARQUISE DE MERTEUIL.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Your damned cousin, the Volanges bitch, wanted me away from Madame de Tourvel: well, now I am and I intend to make her suffer for it. Your plan to ruin her daughter, are you making any progress, is there anything I can do to help, I'm entirely at your disposal.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: Well, yes, I told Danceny you would act as his confidant and advisor. I want you to stiffen his resolve, if that's the phrase. VALMONT frowns, not at all pleased.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: I thought if anyone could help him...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Help? He doesn't need help, he needs hindrances: if he has to climb over enough of them, he might inadvertently fall on top of her. He shakes his head dismissively, gets up and moves over to flop down on a chaise-longue.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I take it he hasn't been a great success,

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: He's been disastrous. Like most intellectuals, he's intensely stupid. VALMONT enjoys this: he looks at MERTEUIL, shaking his he in admiration.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I often wonder how you managed to invent yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I had no choice, did I, I'm a woman. When I came out into society, I was fifteen, nobody had taught me anything:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 34 Continued MERTEUIL (Cont) and it wasn't pleasure I was after, it was knowledge. So I practised detachment. I learned how to smile Pleasantly while, under the table, I stuck a fork into the back of my hand. I became not merely impenetrable, but a virtuoso of deceit. Women are obliged to be far more skilful than men. So of course I had to invent: not only myself, but ways of escape no one else has ever thought of. And I've succeeded, because I always knew I was born to dominate your sex and avenge my own. I operate on a wonderfully simple principle: win or die.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Does that make you infallible?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: When I want a man, I have him; when he wants to tell, he finds he can't. That's the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And was that our story? MERTEUIL pauses before answering: the air is becoming increasingly charged with eroticism.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I wanted you before we'd even met. My self-esteem demanded it. Then, when you began to pursue me, I wanted you so badly. It's the only one of my notions has ever got the better of me. Single combat.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Thank you.

A heavy silence is broken by the sudden opening of the mirrored double-doors. MERTEUIL's MAJORDOMO moves over and murmurs to her. She nods in acknowledgement. The MAJORDOMO sets off again, back towards the door. MERTEUIL indicates a screen, which stands in a distant corner of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: If you'd care to go behind the screen, Vicomte, I've arranged a little scene I hope you may find entertaining. VALMONT frowns at her, puzzled.  ” 60

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 Continued

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Well, hurry. VALMONT rises and moves swiftly across the room. He's in place behind the screen just in time to avoid being seen by MME DE VOLANGES, who hurries in looking slightly flustered, accompanied by the MAJORDOMO. MERTEUIL, who has assumed a grave expression, rises to greet her, kissing her on both cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Your note said it was urgent...

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: It's days now, I haven't been able to think about anything else, I couldn't decide what to do for the best. Please, sit down. VALMONT listens behind the screen, bemused. VOLANGES takes a seat, thoroughly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I have reason to believe that a, how can [ describe it, a dangerous liaison has sprung up between your daughter and the Chevalier Danceny. Behind the screen, VALMONT is dumbfounded by this; he shakes his head, at a loss to understand MERTEUIL's tactics. Meanwhile, VOLANGES is confidently dismissing the suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: No, no, that's completely absurd. Cécile is still a child, she under- Stands nothing of these things; and Danceny is an entirely respectable young man.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Tell me, does Cécile have a great many correspondents?

dialogues.speaker: " YOLANGES
dialogues.text: Why do you ask?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I went into her room at the beginning of this week, I simply knocked and entered; and she was stuffing a letter into the left-hand drawer of her bureau; in which, I couldn't help noticing, there seemed to be a large number of other letters.  “)
60 36 Continued Silence. Behind the screen, VALMONT's mouth is open in admiration and amazement. VOLANGES rises to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: I'm most grateful to you. ['ll see myself out. MERTEUIL rings. VOLANGES stands up, still in a state of mild shock.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Would you think it impertinent if I were to make another suggestion?

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: If my recollection is correct, I overheard you saying to the Vicomte de Valmont that his aunt had invited you and Cécile to stay at her chateau. CLOSE ON VALMONT. His eyes narrow and a smile begins to spread across his face.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: She has, yes, repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: A spell in the country might be the very thing. The MAJORDOMO has returned and MERTEUIL beckons him over. She gestures urgently and VALMONT suddenly realises he is visible in the mirrored: door. He takes evasive action ju in time, as MERTEUIL is speaking to the MAJORDOMO.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Show Madame de Volanges to her , carriage. She embraces VOLANGES warmly, checking that VALMONT is no longer visible. Bowed down with care, VOLANGES shuffles out of the room after the MAJORDOMO. VALMONT emerges from behind the scre as MERTEUIL settles on the chaise-longue. He's lost in admiration. :

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You asked for hindrances.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You are a genuinely wicked woman.  60 Continued 37

dialogues.speaker: MERTEULL
dialogues.text: And you wanted a chance to make my cousin suffer,

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: IT can't resist you.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: T've made it easy for you. VALMONT . But all this is most inconvenient; the Comtesse de Beaulieu has invited me to stay,

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Well, you'll have to put her off.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The Comtesse has promised me extensive use of her gardens. It seems her husband's fingers are not as green as they once were.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Maybe not, ut’ from what I hear, all his friends are gardeners.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ts that so?

dialogues.speaker: MERTELIL
dialogues.text: You want your revenge. I want my revenge, I'm afraid there's really Only one place you cau ey.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Back to Auntie, eh?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Back to Auntie. Where you can also pursue that other matter. You have sone evidence to procure, have you not VALMONT doesn't answer for a moment, He approaches, rever to the tone of. just before MME DE VOLANGES's arrival.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Don't you think it would. be a generous gesture, show a proper confidence in my abilities, to take that evidence-for granted,..?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I need it in writing, Vicomte.  60 61 62 63 38 Continued He's close to her now, giving her his most charming smile She leans her head back, unmoved. Their voices are intima his persuasive, hers amised,

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: And now you must leave me.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Must I? Why?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Because I'm hungry.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, I've quite an appetite myself.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Then go home and eat. He leans in to kiss her, but she turns aside, offering hi her cheek,

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: In writing. He gives up, smiling at her, still in admiration. INT. CECILE'S BEDROOM IN MME DE VOLANGE'S HOUSE Day CECILE looks up with a start as MME DE VOLANGES storms in the room, goes straight to‘her bureau and opens the left- drawer. Her eyes widen in horror as MME DE VOLANGES bring out a handful of letters, INT, DRAWING ROOM IN VALMONT'S HOUSE pay DANCENY is in the process of sealing a letter, when he is Overcome by emotion: he puts down the sealing-wax and sob burying his face in his bands. VALMONT grunts understandi ipkes the seal from between DANCENY's limp fingers and ap it to the wax. Then he puts an arm round DANCENY, who bur his face in VALMONT's chest. VALMONT passes a fastidious hand lightly over DANCENY's hair and picks up the letter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE ROSEMONDE'S CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: The edge of the letter Protrudes from VALMONT's pocket as he moves around the large room. The Autumn sun streams in through the French windows. A WIDER ANGLE shows the four women disposed around the room; MME DE TOURVEL, stretched Out On a Chaise-longue, ashen, Staring. at a book; MME DE VOLANGES, in a window-seat, staring out at the grounds; CELINE, in a corner, working at her embroidery; -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 Continued and MME DE ROSEMONDE, Playing solitaire at the card-table The latter looks up as VALMONT drifts by.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: You'll be pleased to hear, my dear, that Armand is on his feet again and back at work.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Monsieur Armand, whose family you helped so generously.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. He finds a seat, equidistant between TOURVEL and CECILE a stares for a moment at TOURVEL. When she looks up at hin, he looks away quickly, this time at CECILE, who presently becomes aware of his gaze and embarrassed by it. VALMONT turns very quickly back to TOURVEL and is gratified to catch her still looking at him, though she immediately tu away. ROSEMONDE meanwhile turns to address VOLANGES.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: When my nephew was last Staying here, we discovered quite by chance... VALMONT interrupts her, suddenly rising to his feet, stil staring at TOURVEL.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Are you feeling all right, Madame? I'm sorry to interrupt you, Aunt, it seemed to me all of a sudden that Madame de Tourvel didn't look at all well.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: ' I'm...no, I'm quite all right. By now, ROSEMONDE and VOLANGES are on their feet, converg on TOURVEL. As they bear down on her, VALMONT steps back, slips the letter out of his pocket and holds it behind hi back, waving it at CECILE. She's very slow to react, but eventually she grasps the significance of VALMONT's impat ‘gestures, tosses her embroidery aside and stuffs the let in her pocket. Meanwhile, to the others, MME DE TOURVEL continues to be the centre of attention.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Perhaps you need some air. Do you feel constricted in any way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: No, really...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I feel sure Madame de Volanges is right, as usual. A turn around the grounds perhaps.

dialogues.speaker: . ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, a little walk in the garden, it's not too cool, I think. TOURVEL frowns in puzzlement as VOLANGES wraps a shawl round her shoulders and propels her in the direction of the French windows,

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Fresh air will do you the world of good.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: The meal was somewhat heavy, perhaps...

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: I don't believe that can be the cause... 2 During this exchange, CECILE has gathered up her shawl an made to follow the others. As she's spreading it across her shoulders, however, she's startled to find it tugged away from her by VALMONT, who drops it on a chair, murmur between clenched teeth.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Come back for it. She frowns at him for a moment, then follows the still- clucking ladies out into the garden. VALMONT watches with satisfaction as she stops, says a word to her mother and comes hurrying back into the room. VALMONT sits her down, hands her her shawl and sits opposite her, talking very f

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: IL don't want to arouse suspicion, Mademoiselle, so I must be brief. The letter is from the Chevalier Danceny. :

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Yes, I thought so, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Now the handing-over of such letters is a far from easy matter to accomplish. I can't very well create a diversion every dav.  ” ” 63 84 41 Continued At this point VALMONT produces a large key from his waist pocket,

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: So, this key resembles the key to your bedroom, which I happen to know is kept in your mother's room, on the mantelpiece, tied with a blue ribbon. Take it, go up now, attach the blue ribbon to it and put it in place of your bedroom key, which you will then bring to me. I'll be able to get a copy cut within two hours. Then I'll be able to collect your letters and deliver Danceny's without any complications. He drops the key into CECILE's lap.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ob, and in the cupboard by your bed, you'll find a feather and a small bottle of oil, so that you can oil the lock and hinges on the ante-room door. Off you go.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Are you sure, Monsieur, I'm not sure it would be right...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Well, I know Monsieur Danceny has every confidence in you...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Believe me, Mademoiselle, if there's one thing I can't abide, it’s deceitfulness. ’ She hesitates for a moment and then hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TERRACE DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT steps out of the French windows on to the terrace where ROSAMONDE, VOLANGES and TOURVEL. are waiting. -

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Do you know where my daughter is, Vicomte?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I believe she went up to get her shawl,  64 65 66 67 42 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: Oh? I thought she had her shawl.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE VOLANGES'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: CECILE grapples with the blue ribbon, experiencing the greatest difficulty in disentangling it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TERRACE DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT, his expression a little tense, has moved away fr the group of waiting women. He's startled when he looks u to see MME DE TOURVEL bearing down on him, speaking in a fierce undertone.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: If I did feel i11, Monsieur, it would not be difficult to guess who was responsible. VALMONT is too surprised to answer.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You promised to leave here.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And I did.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Then how can you be insensitive enough to return without warning? VALMONT is only too aware that MME DE VOLANGES is now heading purposefully back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me, Madame? He breaks away from her and sets off towards a different entrance into the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE VOLANGES'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: CECILE has almost finished tying the blue ribbon on to the second key, when it Slips from her fingers and drops into the grate. She falls to her knees and tries to fish it out. She can't reach it, Suddenly, the creak of the ante-room door makes her look up in terror. It's VALMONT. He hurries across the room.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Quick. Your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 Continued CECILE indicates the key in the grate. VALMONT's fingers are long enough to reach the ribbon. He fishes the key out and drops it on the mantelpiece. Then he catches sigh of VOLANGES's shawl, picks it up, thrusts it at CECILE an dives behind the door, just as VOLANGES arrives.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I just came up to fetch your shawl. She hands her the shawl and they leave the room. VALMONT waits a few seconds before emerging.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN STAIRCASE DAY
dialogues.text: As MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE arrive at the top of the stairs, so VALMONT arrives at the bottom. They pass on the stairs, VALMONT moving respectfully to one side, and VOLANGES ignoring him. CECILE, a pace behind, takes the opportunity to slip the key into VALMONT's hand, almost dropping it as she does so.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FORMAL GARDENS DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL and VALMONT sit at either end of a bench in the rigidly manicured garden.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Why are you so angry with me?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm not angry. Although since your very first letter spoke of nothing but the disorders of love, I'm certainly entitled to ' be.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I was away almost three weeks and wrote to you only three times. Since I was quite un- able to think about anything but you, some might say I showed heroic restraint.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: But you persisted in writing about your love.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It's true: I couldn't find the etranw~th +m nhmer  a4 69 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You must know it's impossible for me to reciprocate your feelings.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What else could I have written to you about, other than my love? What else is there? I believe I've done everything you've asked of me. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you came back.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: | You've done nothing of the sort. i VALMONT | I left here when you wanted me to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALMONT, momentarily blocked by this, casts around for a way forward. |

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~ All I can offer you, Monsieur, is -) my friendship; can't you accept it?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I could pretend to: but that would be dishonest. The man I used to be would have been content with friend- ship; and set about trying to turn ! it to his advantage. But I've : changed, thanks to you. You've made me a better person: you mustn't now undo your handiwork.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I've no wish to. But equally, I 1 have no wish to hear what you invariably get round to saying.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Surely we don't have to try to avoid each other?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Of course not. Providing you promise not to insult me.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shall obey you in this as in everything. my Rather to her surprise, he rises to his feet and bows formally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 INT. DRESSING-ROOM IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE Day MERTEUIL sits, en negligée, reading a letter.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: ‘We go for a walk together almost every day: a little further every time down the path that has no turning.'

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GROUNDS OF THE CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT and MME DE TOURVEL stroll through parklands, the chateau silhouetted on a ridge behind them, deep in conversation.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I wish you knew me well enough to recognise how much you've changed me. My friends in Paris remarked on it at once. I've become the soul of consideration, charitable, conscientious, more celibate than a monk...

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: More celibate?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, you know the stories one hears in Paris. MME DE TOURVFI. nan't suppress a smile. LONG SHOT: the two of them moving through the autumn landscape.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL continues to read.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "She's accepted my love; I've ’ accepted her friendship; we're both aware how little there is to choose between them. Her eyes are closing,' MERTEUIL looks up from the letter, thoughtful.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANTE-ROOM TO THE VOLANGES' BEDROOMS NIGHT
dialogues.text: The hinges no longer squeak as VALMONT, in bis dressing-g carrying a dark-laatern, closes the door behind him, prod the key, crosses to another door, inserts the key in the lock, turns it, removes and pockets the key, opens the do and advances.

dialogues.speaker: INT, CECILE'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: CECILE is fast asleep inthe large bed. VALMONT closes the door behind him and crosses silently to the bed. He Stands for a moment, contemplating CECILE. Then he puts the lantern down carefully, leans forward and very gently eases back the covers. CECILE stirs but still doesn't wak VALMONT passes his hand through the air, tracing the cont of her body. Finally, he puts his hand over her mouth. She wakes with a start, her eyes wide above his hand. VALMONT smiles and speaks in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Nothing to worry about. He removes his hand. She stares up at him, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Have you brought a letter?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Then what... Instead of answering, he leans forward to kiss her. There a brief, fierce struggle, in which CECILE successfully de herself from the kiss, but is entirely taken by surprise VALMONT plunges a hand up inside her nightdress. Her eyes widen in horror, but her cry is instantly stifled as VALM other hand clamps down on her mouth. She writhes determin for a moment, succeeds in freeing her head and dives acro the bed to reach for the bell-pull. VALMONT leaps on to t bed, grasping her wrist just in time. She grapples with h for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What are you going to tell your mother? How will you explain the fact that I have your key? If I tell her I'm here at your invitation, I have a feeling she'll believe me. CECILE stops struggling, her eyes wide with fear. He's lying beside her on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know, what do you think? His hand goes back up inside her nightdress.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: No, please, don't. Please.  be 74 Continued 47

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: All right. I just want you to give me a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: A kiss?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: That's all.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Then will you go?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Then I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Whatever you say. CECILE flops back on the pillow and closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: All right. VALMONT leans in and gives her a long kiss, his hands roaming as he does so. After a while he pulls away,

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: All right?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: No, I mean, will you go now?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: But you promised.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I promised to go when you gave me a kiss. You didn't give me a kiss. I gave you a kiss. Not the same thing at all. CECILE peers at him miserably. He looks back at her, calm waiting.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: And if I give you a kiss...?  74 75 48 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: That's what I said.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: You really promise?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Let's just get ourselves more comfortable, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Do you? VALMONT disposes the sheet over him, moving on top of her as he does so. He replaces his hand and CECILE reacts wit a start.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Please don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'll take it away. After the kiss.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, yes.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Swear?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I swear. Now put your arms round me. CECILE reaches up and gives him a long, surprisingly inte kiss, her eyes tightly closed. Suddenly she gasps and her eyes open wide with amazement. Slowly VALMONT's hand come up from under the cover. CECILE looks at it, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: See. I told you I'd take my hand away. INT. DINING-ROOM Day MME DE ROSEMONDE sits at the head of the long polished ta with MME DE VOLANGES on her right and CECILE on her left. Further down, on VOLANGES's side is VALMONT; opposite him MME DE TOURVEL. It's breakfast time and the sideboard is groaning with beef and poultry and lamb cutlets. VALMONT is eating heartily; CECILE, on the other hand, stares

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 75 76 717 78 79 49 Continued unseeingly at her food. She looks up. Across the table, VALMONT catches her eye and gives her an imperceptible wi Immediately, she bursts into noisy tears, gets up and hur out of the room. Consternation, except for VALMONT, who, unperturbed, sips at his champagne,

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: I'd better to and see what's wrong if you'll excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Of course, my dear.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shouldn't worry, Madame. The young have such miraculous powers of recuperation. I'm sure she'll soon be back in the saddle. VOLANCES, on her feet already, acknowledges VALMONT with perfunctory smile, as she hurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ANTE-ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Vv: ONT tip-toes in with his dark-lantern. He reaches CECILE's door, brings out his key and turns it in the loc The door does not yield. VALMONT frowns, puzzled and trie again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CECILE'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: The door is bolted on the inside. CECILE sits at her bure writing a letter, tears rolling down her face. She looks up at the SOUND of the key in the lock, then returns with an even fiercer concentration to her letter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRESSING-ROOM IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: MBRTEUIL reads CECILE's letter, a sardonic smile on her f

dialogues.speaker: CECILE, (V.0.)
