dialogues.text: Who else can I turn to in my desparation, Madame? And how can I write the necessary words?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN ENTRANCE TO MME DE ROSEMONDE'S CHATEAU DAY
dialogues.text: A large and elegant carriage draws up outside the chateau The HEAD FOOTMAN, a silver-haired veteran, passes down th steps through the ranks of SERVANTS, who wait at attentio opens the carriage door, lowers the steps and remains bow in anticipation. Presently the MARQUISE DE MERTEUIL emerg from the carriage.  50

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : . 78 = Continued | MME DE ROSEMONDE and MME DE VOLANGES descend between th i ranks of SERVANTS, the latter arriving first and mutter urgently to MERTEUIL as they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: There's something going on, ‘ Cecile won't tell me, you must 1 speak to her at once. 80 INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE ROSEMONDE'S CHATEAU Day MERTEUIL sits on a chaise-longue not far from an open French window. CECILE kneels at her feet, still distraigh ‘

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I thought he'd just come to bring me a letter. But he hadn't. And by the time I realised what he had come for, it was, well, it was too late to stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: > You mean to tell me you're upset . because Monsieur de Valmont has taught you something you've undoubtedly been dying to learn?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: ' What?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: ‘ And am I to understand that what ‘ generally brings a girl to her senses has deprived you of yours?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: , Tell me: you resisted him, did you?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Of course I did, as much as I could,

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: But he forced you? It wasn't that exactly, but I found it almost impossible to defend myself.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Why was that? Did he tie you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 Continued S

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: No. No, but he has a way of putting things. You just can't think of an answer.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Not even no?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I kept saying no all the time; but somehow that wasn't what I was doing. She looks up at MERTEUIL. I'm so ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You'll find the shame is like the pain: you only feel it once.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You really want my advice?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: i Please. ‘ MERTEUIL Allow Monsieur de Valmont to i continue your instruction. : Convince your mother you have forgotten Danceny. And raise no objection to the marriage. CECILE gapes at her, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: With Monsieur de Bastide?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: When it comes to marriage one man is as good as the next; and even the least accommodating is less trouble than a mother.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: ~ So are you saying I'm going to have to do that with three different 5 men?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm saying, you stupid little girl, that provided you take a few elementary precautions, you can do it, or not, with Re many mon am eas Valen nn pe!  4

dialogues.speaker: XK
dialogues.text: 80 81 Continued MERTEUIL (Cont) you like, in as many different ways as you like. Our sex has few enough advantages, you may as well make the most of those you have. CECILE is fascinated: she looks at MERTEUIL with a kind o wild surmise.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: And now here comes your mama, so - remember what I've said and, above all, no snivelling. MME DE VOLANGES arrives from the garden through the French windows, anxiously looking at CECILE.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: How are you feeling now, my dear?

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Oh, much better thank you, Maman.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: You look so tired. I think you should go to bed.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: No, really, I...

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I think you should do as your mother suggests. We can arrange for some- thing to be brought to your room. I'm sure it would do you good.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Well. Perhaps you're right, Madame. And she leaves the room, turning back once to exchange a mischievous glance with MERTEUIL. VOLANGES doesn't see th having turned gratefully back to MERTEUIL.

dialogues.speaker: VOLANGES
dialogues.text: You have such a very good influence on her,

dialogues.speaker: INT. UPSTAIRS CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT, carrying his dark-lantern, leads CECILE along th corridor. They're both in dressing-gowns. He opens a door quietly.  ws

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT leads CECILE into the room; it's much grander than hers, and she looks around, a little awed. Candles burn in strategic emplacements.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Here, you can make as much noise as you like. He puts the lantern down by the bed and presses down on i

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And the mattress is a little harder.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, that's very good. Impulsively, CECILE throws off her things and jumps onto bed. She bounces up and down experimentally and then reaches a hand up to VALMONT.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Come on. VALMONT smiles and then lowers himself gently alongside her on the bed. She grabs at his dressing-gown and he takes her wrists, restraining her.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The first thing you must learn is that there is no necessity whatsoever for haste. He reaches out to caress her. Now. As with every other science, the first principle is to make sure you call everything by its proper : ' name.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I don't see why you have to talk at all.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Without the correct polite vocabulary, how can you indicate what you would like me to do or make me an offer of something [I might find agreeable.

dialogues.speaker: CECTLE
dialogues.text: Surely you just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82tinued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You see, if I do my work adequately, I would like to think you'll be able to surprise Monsieur de Bastide on his wedding night.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Would he be pleased?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, of course, he'll merely assume your mama has done her duty and fully briefed you. ‘ILE bursts out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Maman couldn't possibly talk about anything of the sort. VALMONT . Ican't think why. She was, after all, at one time, one of the most notorious young women in Paris.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Maman?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Certainly. More noted for her enthusiasm than her ability, if I remember rightly. There was a famous occasion, oh, before you were born, this would have been, when she went to stay with the Comtesse de Beaulieu, who tactfully gave her a room between your father's and that of a Monsieur de Vressac, who was her acknowledged lover at the time. Yet in spite of these careful arrangements, she contrived to spend the night with a third party. 2

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I can't believe that, it's just gossip.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, I assure you, it's true.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: How do you know? LMONT looks down at her, a slow smile spreading.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The third nawee ane merest &

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 83 55 ‘ Continued CECILE's jaw drops. For a moment she stares at VALMONT, appalled. Then she bursts out laughing, her laughter even more abandoned than before.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, we can return to this subject later. During the intervals. He caresses her thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You asked me if Monsieur de Bastide would be pleased with your abilities; and the answer is that even if he isn't, I don't believe it would be difficult to find others who would. Education is never a waste. He begins kissing her, his head travelling down her body. He plants a kiss on her stomach and looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I think we might begin with one or two Latin terms.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON EVENING
dialogues.text: MME DE ROSEMONDE is entertaining members of the local nobility and everyone has made an effort to do justice to the occasion. VALMONT and MERTEUIL move through the crowd, resplendent , conversing in an undertone, as they acknowledge the greetings of their acquaintances. VALMONT makes a particularly deep reverence to MME DE VOLANGES an CECILE, at which the former smiles in queasy response.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: So she let you in last night? ‘ VALMONT . Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Thanks to me, I think you'll find. She seems to be under the impression that your original approach was rather...underhand. She waves charmingly at some elderly GUEST. To tell you the truth, the real reason I consented to spend a day at this lugubrious address was that I was hoping to be shown some tear- Stained Kirt Af nanan  q

dialogues.speaker: CY
dialogues.text: 83 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: But I can only assume that no such document exists.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Probably just as well, no doubt you're exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I think you know me better than that.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Can't see her at the moment. He blows a kiss at a WOMAN, who pretends not to notice.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Surely I've explained to you before how much I enjoy watching the battle between love and virtue.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What concerns me is that you appear to enjoy watching it more than you used to enjoy winning it.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: All in good time.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: The century is drawing to its close.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I really don't want to hurry things: Every step she tries to take away from the inevitable conclusion brings her a little nearer to it. And when Bastide and Cécile are married and Madame de Tourvel eventually collapses, we shall tell everyone, shall we not?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I wish I could share your confidence, Vicomte. But I'm beginning to have my doubts about you. Do you really deserve your reputation?  y 83 84 s7 Continued Their travels have brought them back close to MME DE VOLA and CECILE, whom VALMONT surreptitiously indicates.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Isn't it a pity that our agreement does not relate to the task you set me rather than the task I set myself?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I am grateful, of course: but that would have been almost insultingly simple. One does not applaud the tenor for clearing his throat. The pure and unearthly SOUND of a soprano VOICE raised in some religious anthem, as VALMONT and MERTEUIL join a reluctant MME DE VOLANGES.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MUSIC-ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: The VOICE belongs to a tall MAN of melancholy aspect: a castrato. He stands on a dais in front of a small baroque orchestra, singing exquisitely, the veins standing out on his temples, to an attentive audience. VALMONT and MERTEUIL are in the back row, watching. Suddenly, however, VALMONT gives a quite perceptible star which MERTEUIL notices. She follows his eyeline. MME DE TOURVEL,looking frail and beautiful, has entered t room. She makes her way to an isolated seat, quite close the orchestra and at an angle and begins to listen. MERTEUIL turns to look at VALMONT. He's transfixed. Presently, MME DE TOURVEL half-turns to scan the crowd. S looking for VALMONT; and when she sees him she holds his and smiles shyly. VALMONT smiles back: MERTEUIL watches him, with a trace o alarm. MME DE TOURVEL turns back to listen to the music. VALMONT stares, rapt, at her profile. Then he starts agai as MERTEUIL's hand closes on his wrist. He smiles at her sheepishly, aware of being caught out. MME DE TOURVEL is moved by the music. There are tears in eyes. VALMONT is once again lost in contemplation of her profil He doesn't notice now that MERTEUIL is looking at him, he expression considerably disturbed.  cy u 85 86 87 88 89 58

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE CHAPEL DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT arrives late for the service. He's pleased to notice that the seat next to MME DE TOURVEL is empty. Indeed, as she turns and beckons to it, it's clear that s has saved it for him. He arrives, acknowledging her and kneels for a moment's private prayer.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT stands, still fully dressed, in his candle-lit bedroom, his door slightly ajar, his eye to the crack in the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT'S P.O.V. through the crack in the door; MME DE TOURVEL, alone, arrives at the top of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT straightens up and saunters out of his room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT stops, as if surprised, and bows to MME DE TOURVE

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Madame.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Where are you going, Monsieur?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: To the salon.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: There's no-one there. The others have all decided on an early night. He's following her along the corridor now, on the way to her room.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I very much missed our walk today.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I fear with the weather as it is, we can look forward to very few more of them.

dialogues.speaker: L
dialogues.text: 59 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. By this time, they've arrived at the door to her bedroom, which she's opened. She hesitates in the doorway and VALMONT decides to take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: May I?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Of course. Trying to conceal his astonishment, he follows her into the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOURVEL'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT speaks, to cover his entrance into the room, whic is similarly appointed to his own, though somehow far mor sober in feeling.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: But, you see, within a week I shall have concluded my business. TOURVEL stops in her tracks, clearly affected by this new

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Even so, I'm not sure I'll be able to bring myself to leave.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Oh, please. You must! It's an involuntary exclamation; VALMONT knows exactly how to capitalise on it.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Are you still so anxious to get rid of me?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You know the answer to that. I rely on your integrity and generosity. I want to be able to be grateful to you.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Forgive me if I say I don't want your gratitude. I want something altogether deeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Na} 90 60 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I know God is punishing me for my pride. I was so certain nothing like this could ever happen.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Nothing like what?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I can't...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Do you mean love? Is love what you mean? He takes her hand. She starts, but doesn't remove it.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You promised not to speak of it.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: But I must know, I need this consolation at least.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I can't...don't you see...it's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Of course I understand, I don't want you to Say anything, but I must know, I must know if you love me, don't speak, you don't have to speak. I just want you to look at me. Just look. That's all I ask. Long silence. Finally, slowly, MME DE TOURVEL raises her eyes to him. ’

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Yes. They're motionless for a moment. Then. VALMONT releases her hand and puts his arms around her. As he does so, her eyes suddenly go dead and she collapses sideways, obligin him to catch her. She sways in his arms for a moment, the comes to and jerks violently away from him, running half- across the room. Then she bursts into tears. She stands f a moment, sobbing wildly, then rushes at VALMONT, falls t her knees and throws her arms round his legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 91 92 61 Cont inued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: For God's sake, you must leave me, if you don't want to kill me, you must help, it's killing me! VALMONT, somewhat taken aback at first by her intensity, collects himself and lifts her to her feet. For a moment they sway together in an ungainly embrace; then MME DE TOURVEL's sobs cease abruptly and give way to chattering teeth and almost epileptic convulsions. Startled, VALMONT gathers her up in his arms, carries her over and deposits her gently on the bed. The convulsions continue, her teeth are clenched, the blood drained from her face. He leans forward and loosens her bodice as she stares helplessly up at him. Slowly, her features return to normal. He looks down at her, perplexed. Her arms open, she relaxes, her lips part. He starts to lean towards her then suddenly checks himself and looks away, something almost like shame darkening his expression. Her face begi to collapse. He looks back at her, gnawing at his lip. Sh begins to go into shock again and he straightens up, move back across the room and pulls the bell-pull. Her sobs drive him from the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: As VALMONT steps into the corridor, ROSEMONDE's maid, ADE comes hurrying up, struggling into her dressing-gown.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Fetch Madame. Madame de Tourvel has been taken ill. ADELE hurries away and VALMONT steels himself to step bac into the room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOURVEL'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: As VALMONT appears in the doorway, TOURVEL stretches out her hand to him. He crosses and takes it between both of his. He stands, massaging her hand, bemused and thoughtfu He lets go of her hand abruptly as MME DE ROSEMONDE appea shepherded by ADELE.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I heard something as I was passing; she seemed to. be having difficulty breathing.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear, whatever is it?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm all right now.  y

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 93 94 95 62 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shall leave her in your capable hands, Aunt. And still looking strangely abashed, he leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: We must send for a doctor, my dear. MME DE TOURVEL is roused from her rapt contemplation of VALMONT's departure. :

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: No, no, please, I don't need a doctor. I just...come and sit by me for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR NIGHT
dialogues.text: As VALMONT moves back towards his room, lost in thought, he hears a footstep behind him. It's MME DE VOLANGES, on her way to investigate the disturbance. VALMONT makes an authoritative gesture to discourage her from entering TOU room, and she turns away, strangely confused and abashed.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT closes the door behind him and leans his head bac on it, completely mystified.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOURVEL'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: ROSEMONDE's kindly face looks anxiously down at MME DE TOURVEL. They're holding hands. ADELE has left the room. MME DE TOURVEL speaks very quietly, controlling herself with enormous difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: ' TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I must leave this house. I'm most desperately in love. MME DE ROSEMONDE bows her head, unsurprised.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: To leave here is the last thing in the world I want to do, but I'd rather die than have to live with the guilt. Can you understand what I'm saying?  u 95 Continued 63

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Of course. My dear girl. None of this is any surprise to me. The only thing which might surprise one is how little the world changes.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Well, what should I do? What's your advice?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: If I remember rightly, in such matters all advice is useless.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I've never been so unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: EOSEMONDE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to say this: but those who are most worthy of love are never made happy by it. You're too young to have understood that.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: By why, why should that be?

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: Do you still think men love the way we do? No. Men enjoy the happiness they feel; we can only enjoy the happiness we give. They're not capable of devoting themselves exclusively to one person. So to hope to be made happy by love is a certain cause of grief. I'm devoted to my nephew, but what's true of most men is doubly so of him.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: And yet...he could have...just now. He took pity on me, I saw it happen, I saw his decision not to take advantage of me.

dialogues.speaker: ROSEMONDE
dialogues.text: If he has released you, my dear child, you must go. TOURVEL looks up at her. Tears. begin to cascade from the corners of her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: AZOLAN leans over VALMONT, shaking him. VALMONT comes up from the bottom of a deep sleep and wakes with a start

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Get up, sir, quick.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What is it? AZOLAN is already over by the window.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Over here. VALMONT, spurred by the urgency of his tone, scrambles out of bed and joins him at the window.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN ENTRANCE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Below, a carriage pulls away and speeds down the entrance drive. . .

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: AZOLAN turns to the still slightly befuddled VALMONT.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Madame de Tourvel.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What? Suddenly, VALMONT is wide-awake. He issues his orders calmly and decisively. -

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I want you to follow her, right now. Stay close to her. I want ' to know everything. Who she sees, where she goes, what she eats, if she sleeps. Everything. He's fetched what looks like a great deal of money out of his desk.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: That's for bribes, Yours will come later,

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Or not. Now go.  cy 98 99 100 101 65 Continued the shock beginning to show.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN VALMONT'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT looks up as AZOLAN arrives at speed.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And what treasures do you have in store for me today? AZOLAN hands him a letter.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: This, which Julie managed to get to before it was sealed up. It's to Father Anselme. She says he can bring you to see her. VALMONT has run his eye over the letter.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: This is excellent. Deliver it. What news?

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: No visitors. There still hasn't been a single visitor since she got back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL sits staring sightlessly at an open book; beside her, a tray of food, scarcely disturbed. There are dark circles under her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Bit of soup last night but didn't touch the pheasant. Afterwards a cup of tea. Nothing else to report.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN VALMONT'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT, pleased, is handing AZOLAN a fat purse.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: How's Julie?

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Seems a bit keener than she was in the country.

dialogues.speaker: VAT.MONT
dialogues.text: 101 66 Continued AZOLAN sighs, shaking his head gloomily.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: Talk about devotion to duty. VALMONT's MAJORDOMO shows MME DE MERTEUIL and DANCENY into the room. VALMONT dismisses AZOLAN, speaking out of the side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Off you go. Keep it up. AZOLAN and the MAJORDOMO leave as VALMONT greets his visitors.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Madame. My dear boy. DANCENY runs over to him and embraces him impulsively.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Monsieur, for every- thing.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I was afraid I'd been a sad disappointment to you.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: On the contrary, it's you I have to thank for keeping our love alive.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ah, as to love, Cécile thinks of little else.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I had so hoped you'd be able to arrange a meeting between us in the country. ‘ VALMONT Yes. In many respects I found her very open to persuasion; but not, alas, on that issue.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: She said in her letter I couldn't do more myself than you've been doing on my behalf.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: She's a most generous girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: u 101 Continued 67

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I don't know how I can bear to go another two weeks without seeing her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shall have to do our very best to provide some distraction for you. And now if you'd be so kind as to wait in the carriage, there's a matter I must discuss with the Vicomte in private.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Of course. He bows to VALMONT and pumps his hand heartily.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I don't know how I can ever repay you.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Don't give it another thought, it's been delightful. . DANCENY leaves the room and VALMONT and MERTEUIL look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Poor boy. He's quite harmless.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I must say I thought Cécile's letter sounded unusually witty.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: So I should hope: I dictated it.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Ah, Vicomte, I do adore you.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I have a piece of news I hope you might find entertaining: I have reason to believe the next head of the house of Bastide may be a Valmont.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What can you mean?

dialogues.speaker: . VALMONT
dialogues.text: Cécile is two weeks late.  101 Continued 68 MERTEUIL is startled: she frowns, assessing the implicati

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: aren't you pleased?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Your aim was to revenge yourself on Bastide. I've provided him with a wife trained by me to perform quite naturally services you would hesitate to request from a professional and very likely pregnant as well. What more do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Vicomte, I agree, you've more than done your duty. Shame you let the other one slip through your fingers. VALMONT 's expression darkens.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I let her go. Can you imagine?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I was...moved.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Oh, well, then, no wonder you bungled it.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I had no idea she was capable of being so devious.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Poor woman, what else could you expect? To surrender and not be taken, it would try the patience of a saint.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I have an appointment to visit her on Thursday. And this time, I shall be merciless. I'm going to punish her.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm pleased to hear it.  Gy 101 102 103 69 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Why do you suppose we only feel compelled to chase the ones who run away?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Immaturity?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shan't have a moment's peace until it's over, you know. I love her, I hate her, my life's a misery; I've got to have her so I can pass all these feelings on to her and be rid of them. MERTEUIL is not best pleased by his tone.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I think I may have kept our young friend waiting long enough.

dialogues.speaker: . VALMONT
dialogues.text: I shall call on you sometime soon after Thursday. .

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Only if you succeed, Vicomte. I'm not sure I could face another catalogue of incompetence. She pecks him on the cheek and hurries away. VALMONT watches her leave, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FOOTMAN shows. VALMONT and FATHER ANSELME, a stocky Cistercian up the stairs. VALMONT murmurs in FATHER ANSELME's ear and the latter, after a moment's hesitation peels away to sit down on the landing. ’

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE EVENING
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL looks up with a start as her FOOTMAN shows in VALMONT. She stands up, visibly trembling, ethereal with exhaustion. The FOOTMAN waits and is surprised to be dismissed impatiently with a gesture from TOURVEL,

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I understand Father Anselme has explained to you the reasons for my visit.  vy Cy 103 Continued 70

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Yes. He said you wished to be reconciled with me before beginning instruction with him.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: But I see no need for formal reconciliation, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No? When I have, as you said, insulted you; and when you have treated me with unqualified contempt.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Contempt?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You run away from my Aunt's house in the middle of the night; you refuse to answer or even receive my letters: and all this after I have shown a restraint of which I think we are both aware. I would call that, at the very least, contempt.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm sure you understand me better “than you pretend, Monsieur...

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It was me you ran away from, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I had to leave.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And do you have to keep away from me?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: For ever?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I must.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 71 Continued VALMONT moves away from her now, speaking half to himself it seems.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well. I'm as unhappy as you could ever have wanted me to be.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I've only ever wanted your happiness. VALMONT runs across to her, falls to his knees and buries his face in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: How can I be happy without you? Cautiously, as if Plunging it in boiling water, MME DE TOURVEL allows her hand to rest for a few seconds on VALMONT's head. He looks up at her fiercely.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I must have you or die. MME DE TOURVEL scrambles to her feet and retreats across the room. VALMONT remains on his knees, his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Death it is. She looks back at him, distraught. He rises to his feet, calmer now.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I'm not used to passion. At least this is the last time. So be calm.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: It's difficult when you're in this state, Monsieur.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, well, it won't last very long.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I understood you approved of the choice my duty has compelled me to make.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes. And your choice has determined mine.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Whirnh ge whaes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 72 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The only choice capable of putting an end to my suffering. TOURVEL's eyes are full of fear.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean? VALMONT puts his hands on her arms and almost shakes her.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Listen. I love you. You've no idea now much. Just remember I've made far more difficult sacrifices than the one I'm about to make. Now goodbye. He pulls away from her, but she clutches at his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Let me go.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You must listen to me!

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: No ! During this exchange they have been struggling, he to free himself, she to hang on to him. Now she collapses into his arms and the struggle resolves into a long kiss. Then he sweeps her up in his arms, carries her across the room and gently sets her down on the ottoman. She bursts into tears and clutches on to him as if she's drowning. Eventually he speaks, his voice unusually tender.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Why should you be so upset by the idea of making me happy? Gradually she stops crying, looking up at him.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Yes. You're right. I can't live either unless I make you happy. So I promise. No more refusals and no more regrets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 104 105 106 73 Continued He leans in and kisses her gently. Then he looks at her for a second and they begin tearing at one another's clothes, suddenly both equally ravenous.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LANDING EVENING
dialogues.text: FATHER ANSELME shifts uneasily, bemused by the unexpected SOUNDS coming from behind the closed doors of the drawing room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN STAIRCASE AND LANDING IN MERTEUIL'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT springs up the staircase, easily outpacing the puffing MAJORDOMO.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Success!

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: At last. INT. GRAND SALON Day They're both seated: VALMONT exhilarated, MERTEUIL a trifle frosty.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I arrived about six.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Yes, I think you may omit the details of the seduction, they're never very enlivening: just describe the event itself.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It was...unprecedented. MERTEUIL's facing away from him now, so he's unable to se (or discern from her voice which remains icy calm) that for her, every word is like a dagger.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It had a kind of charm L don't think I've ever experienced. before.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWLNG-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE EVENING
dialogues.text: VALMONT. and. TOURVEL entwined on an ottoman, their cloth scattered around.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Once she'd surrendered, she behaved with perfect candour. Total mutual delirium.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN MERTEUIL'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on MERTEUIL.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Which for the first time ever with me outlasted the pleasure itself. She was astonishing.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL sits up now; and VALMONT kneels at her feet, his head in her lap. She strokes his hair, her expression a strange mixture of exaltation and sadness.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: So much so that I ended by falling on my knees and pledging her eternal love. And do you know, at the time...

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on VALMONT, as he realises he's allowed himself, pe unwisely, to be carried ‘away.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: «-.and for several hours afterwards, I actually meant it.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It's extraordinary, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Is it? It sounds to me perfectly commonplace.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, I assure you. But of course the best thing about it is that I am now in a position to be able to claim my reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a] 75 110 Continued MERTEUIL rises. and turns to face him. She considers him coldly for a moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You mean to say you persuaded her to write a letter as well, in the course of this awesome encounter?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, I didn't necessarily think you were going to be a stickler for formalities.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: In any case, I think I may have to declare our arrangement null and void.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm not accustomed to being taken for granted. :

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: But there's no question of that.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: And I've no wish to tear you away from the arms of someone so astonishing.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: We've always been frank with one another.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: And as a matter of fact, I have also taken a new lover, who, at 1 the moment, is proving more than satisfactory.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh? And who is that?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I am not in the mood for confidences this evening. Don't let me keep you. She rises to her feet decisively. VALMONT follows suit, momentarily at a loss.

dialogues.speaker: CORRIDOR OF MIRRORS DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT follows MERTEUIL, as she moves. briskly along the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You can't seriously imagine IL prefer her to you?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You may genuinely be unaware of this. But I can see quite plainly that you're in love with this woman. VALMONT stops in his tracks, shocked by the suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: "VALMONT
dialogues.text: No. Not at all. MERTEUIL turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Have you forgotten what it's like to make a woman happy: and to be made happy yourself?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I...of course not.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: We loved each other once, didn't we? I think it was love. And you made me very happy.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And I could again. We just untied the knot, it was never broken.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Illusions of course, are by their nature sweet.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I have no illusions. I lost them on my travels. Now I want to come home. She shakes her head, a hint of melancholy in her smile.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND STAIRCASE DAY
dialogues.text: As they reach the top of the stairs, VALMONT takes her in When they separate, there's tenderness in her eyes. .  Cy

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: This infatuation: it won't last. But, for the moment, it's beyond my control. She takes her hands away and turns, her expression harden again.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR OF MIRRORS DAY
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL passes along the corridor, her head sunk in thought. She opens the secret door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL emerges from her secret door and smiles at someo OUT OF SHOT.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S DRAWING-ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: VALMONT sits at his desk, writing.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I'd sacrifice anything or anybody to you, you know that. I genuinely believe I've never been unfaithful to you.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S GRAND SALON DAY
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL sits at a small escritoire, writing.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: There's no necessity, my dear Vicomte, for you to work on me in this, let's be frank, mechanical ' fashion.. I'm obliged to go away for a couple of weeks, but I'm well aware of our arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET EVENING
dialogues.text: A large carriage passes, MERTEUIL's pale face at the window. There's someone next to her in the shadows, unrecognisahle.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: On my return you and L will spend a single night together. I'm sure we shall find it quite sufficient.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT lies in bed, rereading the letter, a half-smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We shall enjoy it enough to regret that it's to be our last; but then we shall remember that regret is an essential component of happiness. All this, of course, providing you are able to procure this famous letter.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S DRAWING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: VALMONT is pouring some more champagne for EMILIE, when AZOLAN hurries into the room and murmurs in his ear. Whatever he says seems to be an unpleasant surprise to VALMONT.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: All right, give me a moment. AZOLAN bows and leaves the room as VALMONT turns to EMILI

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: A woman?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: A lady, we might even say.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: Oh, well, then. She swallows her champagne and rises to her feet. Not the one you wrote that letter to?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The very one.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: I enjoyed that.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And you proved a most talented desk.

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: I'd love to see what she looks like.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, you can't.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL AND STAIRCASE DAY
dialogues.text: AZOLAN, moving slowly, precedes MME DE. TOURVEL on the st

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S DRAWING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: EMILIE is about to leave by a side-entrance, when VALMONT suddenly checks her, a strange, reckless excitement in hi eyes.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Do you have an appointment for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: Few friends for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And after dinner?

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: Nothing firm. VALMONT opens a drawer and counts out some money.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRCASE AND LANDING DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL pushes past AZOLAN in her eagerness; then stops dead in the entrance to the drawing-room.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S DRAWING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE TOURVEL'S P.O.V.: EMILIE is taking the money from VALMONT. .

dialogues.speaker: EMILIE
dialogues.text: I'll be there. She walks towards MME DE TOURVEL, staring at her with undisguised fascination. MME DE TOURVEL returns her gaze, miserably confused. VALMONT watches, plainly fascinated. At the last minute, just as she's leaving the room, EMILIE is suddenly convul with mirth. She vanishes, helplessly shaking with laughte VALMONT hurries over to MME DE TOURVEL, who now looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: This is an unexpected Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Evidently. eee lee ‘ay from him as she sper"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 123) Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT ,
dialogues.text: Take no notice of Emilie; she's notoriously eccentric.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I know that woman.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I'd be surprised.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: She's been pointed out to me at the Opera.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes, well, she is striking.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: She's a courtesan. Isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I suppose, in a manner of speaking... But MME DE TOURVEL turns and begins to hurry out of the room. VALMONT catches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I disturbed you.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Of course you haven't disturbed me, I'm overjoyed to see you.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Please let me go now.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, I can't, this is absurd.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Let go! ’ : She wrenches free and he has to put his arms round her and pinions her to prevent her from leaving. By now, she's sobbing blindly.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Let's sit down...

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: And you will never be received at my house again! She struggles violently and finally goes limp. He helps her over to a sofa and sits her down.  v 123 Continued She watches calm. 81

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Now listen.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I don't want your lies and excuses!

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Just hear me out, that's all I ask. VALMONT, transfixed, as he speaks with unruffled

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I cannot unlive the years I lived before I met you and during those years, I had a wide acquaintance, the majority of whom were no doubt undesirable in one respect or another. Now it may surprise you to know that Emilie, in common with many others of her. profession and character, is kind-hearted enough to take an interest in those less fortunate than herself. She has, in short, the free time and the inclination to do a great deal of charity work: donations to hospitals, soup for the poor, protection for animals, anything which touches her senti- mental heart. From time to time, I make small contributions to her purse. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT ,
dialogues.text: My relations with Emilie have for some years now been quite blameless. She's even done a little secretarial work for me. Since I now know your feelings on the matter, I shall take steps to ensure she is never received here again.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Why did she laugh?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I've no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 124 82 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Does she know about me?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No doubt she made what, in view of my past, must be regarded as a fair assumption. MME DE TOURVEL seems almost convinced.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I want to believe you.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I knew you were coming up, you were announced. Do you seriously imagine, if I'd felt the slightest guilt about Emilie, I would have allowed you to see her?

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I-suppose not.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No. She looks at him, her eyes clear and candid.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. VALMONT flinches, a look of real guilt appearing. He takes her in his arms and she buries her face in his ches weeping softly.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no, it's I who must apologise. It was most insensitive of me.
MME DE TOURVEL lies in VALMONT's arms. He looks down at her, profoundly contented.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I didn't think it was possible for me to love you more, but your jealousy... He breaks off, genuinely moved. MME DE TOURVEL looks up at him, speaks with the utmost simplicity.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: I love you so much.  a 124 125 126

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 ct a 83 Continued VALMONT draws her up so that she's lying on top of him; and kisses her, his expression uncharacteristically tende

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: When will you start writing to me again?

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S VILLA DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE MERTEUIL, en deshabille, sits at the dressing- table in her suburban love-nest, reading a letter. In the background a sleeping form, unstirring in the bed.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I have the piece of paper you require and hope I may expect to see you very soon.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. COURTYARD OF MME DE VOLANGES'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT, wrapped up against the blustery wind and wintry rain, encounters the CONCIERGE in the courtyard. He hands over a sum of money and the CONCIERGE admits him by a side-door.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You'll be the very first to hear when I return. In the meantime, I hope you are not neglecting your little pupil.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CECILE'S BEDROOM . NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT lies with CECILE in her large four-poster. They speak in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: ’ But where can Danceny. be?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I told you, I have all my people out looking: and no trace of him. The door suddenly bursts open. CECILE suppresses a shriek VALMONT, who is nearer the door, gets up after a few seco and tiptoes towards the gaping doorway. No one. He closes the door with a Sigh of relief and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Only the wind. He turns back to discover that CECILE has vanished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cy 128 129 130 131 84 Continued

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Where are you? There's a groan from the far side of the bed. Hurrying over, VALMONT discovers that CECILE has jammed herself in her panic into the tiny space between the bed and the wall. He helps her up, smiling: but CECILE looks anguished.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Nothing to worry about.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Yes there is. I'm bleeding.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: The same windy and rainy night. MERTEUIL's carriage turns in at the entrance and comes to a stop in the courtyard. The PORTER emerges from his lodge with a large open umbre as FOOTMEN converge on the carriage. Lurking in the archway which leads out to the street is AZOLAN. He moves so as to stay out of sight, peering into the courtyard to try to identify the occupants of the carriage. After a while, he reacts, with an expression of surprise and cynical amusement.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CORRIDOR OF MIRRORS IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The house is deserted. VALMONT moves stealthily down the mirrored corridor, surrounded and apparently pursued by h reflections. He stops and hesitates, looking from one mir to another. Then he remembers and applies pressure to one opening it to reveal the stone spiral staircase.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPIRAL STAIRCASE NIGHT
dialogues.text: ’ VALMONT closes the mirror door behind him. Pitch blacknes He begins to ascend quickly and cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BEDROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Candle-light. DANCENY lies in MERTEUIL's arms. They haven't undressed yet. Suddenly, the cupboard door opens and VALMONT appears, giving DANCENY a hideous shock. MERTEUIL covers her surprise far more effectively.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Your porter appears to be under the impression you are still out of town.  ©) cy 131 Continued 85

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I have in fact only just returned.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Without attracting the attention of your porter. I think it may be time to review your domestic arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm exhausted. Naturally I instructed the porter to inform casual callers that I was out. VALMONT checks a retort and turns instead, smiling, to DANCENY.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: And you here as well, my dear young friend. The porter would seem to be having a somewhat erratic evening.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I, erm, yes.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, it's you I'm looking for.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Mademoiselle Cécile returns to Paris after an absence of over two months. What do you suppose is uppermost in her mind? Answer, of course, the longed-for reunion _ with her beloved Chevalier.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Vicomte, this is no time to make mischief.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Nothing could be further from my mind, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Imagine her distress and alarm when her loved one is nowhere to be found. I've had to do more innwaviocing than ne Tentinng 2 Lee  vy c 131 132 86 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: But how is she? Is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Well, no, to be quite frank. I'm sorry to tell you she's been ill. DANCENY is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, my friend, the surgeon has declared her well on the road to recovery. But you can well imagine how desparate I've been to find you.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Of course, my God, how could I not have been here at such a time? How can I ever forgive myself? His voice trails away, as he becomes aware of MERTEUIL's withering glance.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: But, look, I hate to be the bearer of bad tidings. All is well now with Cécile, I assure you. And I sharn't disturb you further. He produces a piece of paper from an inside pocket.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: It's just that I have something to show the Marquise.
MERTEUIL looks up sharply: he's succeeded in catching her interest.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL finishes reading the letter and hands it back to VALMONT .

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I see she writes as badly as she dresses. Before VALMONT can respond, she changes the subject.  iy

dialogues.speaker: XQ
dialogues.text: uy 132 Continued 87

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Is it really true the little one has been ill?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Not so much an illness, more a refurbishment.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT"
dialogues.text: A miscarriage.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Oh, Vicomte, I am sorry. Your son and Bastide's heir.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Isn't there something else we should be discussing?

dialogues.speaker: . MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I do hope you're not going to be difficult about Danceny.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I know Belleroche was pretty limp, but I think you could have found a livelier replacement than that mawkish schoolboy.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Mawkish or not, he's completely devoted to me. And, I suspect, better equipped to provide me with happiness and pleasure than you. In your present mood.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I see. He ‘lapses into an injured silence. Then MERTEUIL smiles coquettishly.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: If I thought you would be your Old charming self, I might invite you to visit me one evening next week.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I still love you, you see, in spite of all your faults and MY camnlainee  y wy 133 134 88

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND STAIRCASE NIGHT
dialogues.text: MERTEUIL leads VALMONT, holding his hand. At the top of the grand staircase, he turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're not going to impose some new condition before you agree to honour your obligation? Pause. MERTEUIL considers how best to respond. Finally she speaks with deadly precision and calm.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I have a friend, who became involved with an entirely un- suitable woman. Whenever any of us pointed this out to him, he invariably made the same feeble reply: it's beyond my control, he would say. He was on the verge of becoming a laughing-stock. At which point, another friend of mine, a woman, decided to speak to him seriously. She explained to him that his name was in danger of being ludicrously associated with this phrase for the rest of his life. So do you know what he did?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I feel sure you're about to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: He went round to see his mistress and bluntly announced he was leaving her. As you might expect, she protested vociferously. But to everything she said, to every objection she made, he simply ' replied: it's beyond my control. Good night. She flits away along the landing. VALMONT stands there for quite some time before beginning his descent. He walks down the stairs, his heart heavy and his head bowed

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: There's a fire burning in the grate. MME DE TOURVEL paces anxiously up and down. The door opens and the FOOTMAN shows in VALMONT. She runs across to him, unable to conceal her delight and, as the FOOTMAN leaves, she buries herself in his afms. He embraces her, his expression strained and wearv.  q vy 89 134 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: You're only five minutes late, but I get so frightened. I become convinced I'm never going to see you again. VALMONT holds her close, his resolution ebbing away. He kisses her lingeringly.

dialogues.speaker: TTOURVEL
dialogues.text: Is it like that for you? VALMONT detaches himself from her, turns away, and takes a few paces, steeling himself. Then he turns back to her, his expression icy.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Yes. At this moment, for example, I'm quite convinced I'm never going to see you again. TOURVEL doesn't understand: but she feels an automatic stab of fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'm so bored, you see. It's beyond my control.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: After all, it's been four months. So, what I say. It's beyond my control.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Do you mean...you don't love me ‘ any more?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: My love had great difficulty out- lasting your virtue. It's beyond my control.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: It's that woman, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You're quite right, I have been deceiving you with Emilie. Among others. It's beyond my control.  w ae) 90 134 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: There's a woman. Not Emilie, another woman. A woman I adore. And I'm afraid she's insisting I give you up. It's beyond my control. Suddenly MME DE TOURVEL rushes at him, fists flailing. They grapple silently and grimly for one moment, before she screams at hin.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Liar!

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You're right, I ama liar. It's like your fidelity, a fact of life, no more nor less irritating. Certainly, it's beyond my control.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Stop it, don't keep saying that!

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Sorry. It's beyond my control. MME DE TOURVEL screams in anguish and collapses, falling against the ottoman.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Why don't you take another lover? She bursts into tears, shaking her head and moaning incoherently.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Just as you like. It's beyond -My control.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Do you want to kill me? VALMONT strides over to her, takes her by the hair and jerks her head up.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Listen. Listen to me. You've given me great pleasure. But I just can't bring myself to regret leaving you. It's the way of the world. Quite beyond my control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 134 135 136 137 138 139 91 Continued He lets her go and she collapses full-length, moaning and sobbing helplessly. He hurries from the room. She remains where she is, utterly distraught.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LANDING AND STAIRCASE DAY
dialogues.text: Outside the door VALMONT has stopped. He can hear the SOUND of MME DE TOURVEL's weeping. He closes his eyes and leans his head back against the door for a moment, his expression tormented and queasy. Then he sets off at a run, leaping down the stairs and out of the front door as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: The VICOMTE DE VALMONT's carriage moves through swirling fog.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CARRIAGE NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT is alone, pale and preoccupied. He taps against the partition and the carriage draws up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ENTRANCE TO MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: VALMONT jumps down from the carriage and calls up to the coachman.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning, early.

dialogues.speaker: COACHMAN
dialogues.text: My lord. He flicks his whip and the carriage moves off. VALMONT sets off towards the entrance, a black shape cutting through the fog.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GRAND SALON IN MME DE MERTEUIL'S HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The two fires at either end of the great room reflect in the mirrored doors and sparkling chandeliers. Furniture has been drawn up round the fires, forming two islands of objects, leaving the centre of the room a bare arena. MME DE MERTEUIL, alone in the room, sits at a small escritoir, writing. The mirrored doors open and VALMONT appears in the doorway, once again unannounce MERTEUIL looks up: she's unpleasantly surprised to see him, but overcomes her alarp.  92 , 139 Continued ce

dialogues.speaker: _ MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: This ts not your appointed evening.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, but I wanted to ask you: that story you told me, how did it end?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: . VALMONT
dialogues.text: Well, once this friend of yours had taken the advice of his lady-friend, did she take him back?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Am I to understand...?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The day after our last meeting, I broke with Madame de Tourvel on the grounds that it was beyond my control. et A slow smile of great satisfaction spreads across MERT face. : “

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You didn't!

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I certainly did.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: But how wonderful of you.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You kept telling me my reputation was in danger, but I think this may well turn out to be my most famous exploit. ( believe it ‘ gets a new standard. Only one thing could possibly bring me greater glory.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: r To win her back. oa MERTEUIL “ You think you could?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I don't see why not.  139 Continued Silence. MERTEUIL, on the other hand, has never seemed more serene. 93

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why not: because when one woman strikes at the heart of another, she seldom misses; and the wound is invari- ably fatal.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes: I'm also inclined to see this as one of my greatest. triumphs.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: There's nothing a woman enjoys as much as a victory over another woman.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Except, you see, Vicomte, my victory wasn't over her.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Of course it was, what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: It was over you. VALMONT's eyes are suddenly full of fear.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: You loved that woman, Vicomte. What's more you still do. Quite desperately. If you hadn't been So ashamed of it, how could you have treated her so viciously? You couldn't bear even the vague possibility of being laughed at. And this has proved something I've always suspected. That vanity and happiness are incompatible. VALMONT is very shaken. He has to make an effort to be able to resume, his voice ragged with strain.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The fact remains, it's now your turn to make a sacrifice.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Danceny must go.  vd 139 Continued 94

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I've been more than patient about this little whim of yours, but enough is enough.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: One of the reasons I never re-married, despite a quite bewildering range of offers, was the determination never again to be ordered around. I must therefore ask you to adopt a less marital tone of voice.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: She's ill, you know. I've made her ill. For your sake. So the least you can do is get rid of that colourless youth.

dialogues.speaker: . MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I should have thought you'd have had enough of* bullying women for the time being. VALUONT's face hardens.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Right. I see I shall have to make myself very plain. I have come to spend the night. I shall not take at all kindly to being turned away.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I am sorry. ‘I'm afraid I've made other arrangements. A grim satisfaction begins to enliven VALMONT's features.

dialogues.speaker: . VALMONT
dialogues.text: Ah. I knew there was something.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Danceny isn't coming. Not tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: What do you mean? How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I know because I've arranged for him to spend the night with Cécile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 95 139 Continued Silence. VALMONT smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Now I come to think of it, he did mention he was expected here. But when I put it to him that he really would have to make a choice, I must say he didn't hesitate. He's coming to see you tomorrow to explain; and to offer you, do I have this right, yes, I think I do, his eternal friendship. As you said, he's completely devoted to you.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: That's enough, Vicomte.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right. Shall we go up?

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Shall we what?

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Go up. Unless you prefer this, if memory serves, rather purgatorial sofa.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: I believe it's time you were going.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No. I don't think so. We made an arrangement.. I really don't think I can allow myself to be taken advantage of a moment longer.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: . Remember I'm better at this than ' you are.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Perhaps. But it's always the best swimmers who drown. Now. Yes or no? Up to you, of course. I merely confine myself to remarking that a no will be regarded as a declaration of war. So. One single word is all that is required.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 139 140 141 142 96 Continued She looks at him evenly for a moment, almost long enough for him to conclude that she has made her answer. But she hasn't. It follows now, calm and authoritative.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: War.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN
dialogues.text: There's snow on the ground: and the CAMERA PANS past bare trees in the grey dawn light.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My dear Chevalier Danceny, there is something, as I bid you farewell, that I feel I should tell you. The CAMERA comes to rest on DANCENY, who's in his shirtsl pacing impatiently, pulling on a leather gauntlet. Beside is aman in black, his SECOND, holding an épee. DANCENY ta it from him, his breath rising on the air.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: It is not only that he betrayed you with Cécile: it's the pleasure he took in making you ridiculous. ANOTHER ANGLE reveals the whole of the clearing, the snow fresh, if not very deep; and VALMONT, who is calmly makin his selection from a case of épées, held open for him by AZOLAN. He weighs now one and now the other in his hand. Eventually he chooses one and lays it on the ground, whil AZOLAN helps him off with his coat and on with a black gl Then he picks up the sword and approaches DANCENY. They take up the en-garde position. At a sign from AZOLAN, the duel begins, fierce and determined, VALMONT's skill again DANCENY's aggression. For some time, they're evenly match with VALMONT clearly a talented swordsman, looking the mo dangerous. Indeed, quite soon, he seems to have DANCENY a his mercy; but he turns aside at the crucial moment and mowes away, looking surprised at himself.

dialogues.speaker: INT. VALMONT'S BEDROOM DAY
dialogues.text: As in Scene 124, VALMONT draws up MME DE TOURVEL, so that she's lying on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONVENT DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE leave their carriage and move through the snow to the entrance of the convent.  sa 143 144 145 146 147 148 97

dialogues.speaker: INT. PRIVATE ROOM IN THE CONVENT DAY
dialogues.text: A NUN shows VOLANGES and CECILE into a plain cell, where MME DE TOURVEL lies in a curtained bed, deathly pale.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN
dialogues.text: VALMONT returns to the attack: they cut and parry with immense energy. Then VALMONT skids in the snow and DANCEN more by luck than good judgment, succeeds in wounding him whichever is not his sword arm. DANCENY immediately withd according to the rules. VALMONT looks down at the wisp of blood staining his torn sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MADAME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM IN THE CONVENT DAY
dialogues.text: The SURGEON's curved blade cuts at the vein on the inside of MME DE TOURVEL's elbow and dark blood begins to flow into a small siiver bowl.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN
dialogues.text: VALMONT shakes his head as if to clear his mind and resum the en-garde position. The duel continues. This time it's DANCENY who looks to have the initiative. VALMONT seems t have lost heart, or even interest; and at one point when a too-enthusiastic attack by DANCENY leaves him wide open VALMONT fails to take advantage of a golden opportunity. This seems to revive VALMONT's vigour for a moment and he beats DANCENY back only to relent at the last minute and turns his back on him. He moves back towards the centre of the clearing, closing his eyes briefly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAWING-ROOM IN MME DE TOURVEL'S HOUSE EVENING
dialogues.text: As in Scene 109, VALMONT kneels with his face in MME DE TOURVEL's lap. ExT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN VALMONT turns back to face DANCENY. Now he hardly seems t be trying at all, simply parrying his thrusts. Then he counter-attacks, but so rashly that he almost seems to run onto DANCENY's blade, which enters him just below the heart. There's a moment of mutual shock, then DANCENY withdraws his sword and VALMONT staggers a couple of step before collapsing. AZOLAN hurries over to him.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: I'm cold. AZOLAN runs to get his coat. DANCENY turns to his SECOND.  y 148 98 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Fetch the surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: Do as I say! The SECOND hurries away as AZOLAN drapes VALMONT's coat around him. DANCENY stands alone, uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: A moment of your time. DANCENY reluctantly approaches.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Two things: a word of advice, which of course you may ignore, but it is honestly intended; and a request.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: The advice is: be careful of the Marquise de Merteuil.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: You must permit me to treat with scepticism anything you have to say about her.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I must tell you: in this affair, we are both her creatures. Painfully, he reaches into his coat pocket and brings out a bundle of letters.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: As I believe her letters to me will prove. He hands DANCENY the letters. After a moment's thought, DANCENY speaks.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: And the request?

dialogues.speaker: VALSIONT
dialogues.text: I want you to get somehow to see Madame de Tourvel...

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I understand she's very ill.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM AT THE CONVENT DAY
dialogues.text: MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE sit watching over MME DE ‘’OUR

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: That's why this is most important to me. I want you to tell her I can't explain why I broke with her as I did, but that since then my life has been worth nothing. During this, to MME DE VOLANGES's horror, MME DE TOURVEL suddenly wrenches at the bandage at her elbow, opening the wound and causing it to bleed again.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CONVENT EVENING
dialogues.text: DANCENY rides ‘up to the forbidding walls of the convent and dismounts.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I pushed the blade in deeper than you just have, my boy, and I want you to help me withdraw it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: DANCENY leans over MME DE TOURVEL, talking to her, unhear MME DE VOLANGES and CECILE wait in the background.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Tell her it's lucky for her that I've gone and I'm glad not to have to live without her. Tell her her love was the only real ‘ happiness I've ever known. MME DE TOURVEL raises a hand and DANCENY stops speaking.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Enough. She looks up at DANCENY.

dialogues.speaker: TOURVEL
dialogues.text: Draw the curtains. DANCENY rises and draws the curtains on her bed.  wy 152 153 154 100

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN
dialogues.text: CLOSE on DANCENY: tears are rolling down his cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Will you do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I will. The silence is broken by snatches of birdsong.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE TOURVEL'S ROOM EVENING
dialogues.text: A NUN is lighting candles at the foot of MME DE TOURVEL's bed. Through the curtains, her motionless shape. She's dead. MME DE VOLANGES is by the bed. Ina corner, DANCENY murmurs to CECILE.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I've made copies of her letters and sent them to everyone I could think of.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: Letters about me? DANCENY doesn't answer. CECILE shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: We made it very easy for them.

dialogues.speaker: DANCENY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You'll never see me again. He hurries from the room. The NUN draws back the curtains as CECILE approaches MME'DE VOLANGES.

dialogues.speaker: CECILE
dialogues.text: I went to see the Mother Superior. I asked her to let me come back ' here. For good. VOLANGES looks at her aghast. CECILE turns away from her and watches as the NUN covers MME DE TOURVEL's waxen face

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOIS DE VINCENNES DAWN
dialogues.text: DANCENY raises a hand to brush away his tears. AZOLAN loo over at him indignantly.

dialogues.speaker: AZOLAN
dialogues.text: It's all very well doing that now.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: Let him be.  154 155 156 157 101 Continued We see VALMONT for the first time in this scene. All around him the snow is red with his blood. He raises a hand towards DANCENY.

dialogues.speaker: VALMONT
dialogues.text: He had good cause. It's something I don't believe anyone has ever been able to say about me. Before DANCENY can take his hand, he slumps back. He's dead. .

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM DAY
dialogues.text: CLOSE on MERTEUIL's face as she utters a great cry of anger and frustration. She sweeps all her perfume-boxes off the dressing-table. Then she smashes everything in the room she can possibly break, ornaments, mirrors, glas jars. She winces suddenly and looks down. She's cut her finger slightly. The sight of her blood seems to calm her She looks up at the circle of SERVANTS, cowering around t margins of the room, appalled.

dialogues.speaker: MERTEUIL
dialogues.text: Get out. All of you. They hurry out in something of a stampede. MERTEUIL stand desolate in a field cf glittering debris. Her head comes down again, contorted with misery and rage.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MERTEUIL'S BOX AT THE OPERA EVENING
dialogues.text: It's before curtain-up and MERTEUIL moves to the front of the box to contemplate the house. Three boxes away a dist inguished-looking middle-aged COUPLE are doing the s thing. MERTEUIL bows to them. To her surprise, they turn away from her, ignoring her ostentatiously. She turns to look down at the orchestra, frowning; and becomes aware that the crowd below are murmuring to one another and pointing up at her. Gradually, the hum dies and there's silence in the theatre. Everyone in the stalls is looking up at her. Suddenly, there's a hiss and then, growing qui in volume and intensity, a torrent of hissing and booing. MERTEUIL absorbs it for a moment, then turns on her heel and, moving with deliberation and a certain dignity, leav the box.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MME DE MERTEUIL'S DRESSING-ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Everything is back exactly as it was, leaving no trace of MERTEUIL's rampage. She, in her négligee, sits at her dressing-table, alone, reméving her make-up. As it comes  157 158 a] em) 102 Continued . off, a new MERTEUIL seems for the first time to be reveal weary, fragile, vulnerable almost. She looks at her reflection with the anxiety someone feels in the presence of their only friend: and the image slowly FADES TO BLACK

dialogues.speaker: CAPTION ON BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: And from then on, her soul was written on her face. 23rd April, 198
